title: madeleine mccann latest news update
story: German national Christian B, a -year-old convicted paedophile, was named as the prime suspect in the case of three-year-old Madeleine, who vanished in Portugal in .Prosecutors are now re-examining the case of nine-year-old Peggy Knobloch, who was killed after vanishing near her home in .Christian B has also been linked to three other murders as well, including the disappearance of a six-year-old boy in Portugal in  and a five-year-old girl in Germany in .Authorities in Belgium have also linked him to the murder of missing -year-old Carola Titze, who disappeared while on holiday in De Haan in .Christian B “freaked out” in  as his staff at the kiosk-bar he ran discussed the Madeleine McCann case and then shouted: “The child is dead and that’s a good thing.”Barmaid Lenta Johlitz, , revealed: “Once he was completely freaked out when we were sitting talking with friends about the Madeleine case.“He wanted us to stop. He cried out, ‘The child is dead now and that’s a good thing’, then he said: ‘You can make a body disappear quickly. Pigs also eat human flesh’.”Christian B is currently eligible for parole having served two-thirds of his sentence for drug offences - but German legal experts say it is unlikely to go through as he is under investigation for murder.Follow our live blog below for all the latest news and updates.Portuguese prosecutors have confirmed Madeleine McCann suspect Christian B has two convictions in the country.It was reported last week that the -year-old had served prison sentences in Portugal, but authorities have now confirmed his criminal record.There had been no official recognition of media reports about the suspect’s criminal record in the country.Last night prosecutors took the unusual step of confirming his criminal record, saying Christian B was convicted of “disobedience” and “theft”.A spokesman for the Faro District of the Portuguese Public Prosecution Service said: “In the last few days, several news articles have been published linking the German national suspected of involvement in Madeleine McCann’s disappearance to other court cases that took place in the Faro district.“In order to clary the matter, the Public Ministry has been examining its records and has so far managed to collect the following information.“The Maddie suspect was convicted of disobedience in one case and of theft in another.“Five requests for international judicial cooperation were also found in which the name of the suspect is mentioned.“One of the requests is related to a case actioned against unknown people and closed in February , and four related to the investigation into Madeleine McCann’s disappearance.”Local media had reported that the -year-old spent two months in Evora Prison, in central Portugal, and nine months in jail in the Algarve for petrol theft in . On  May , the politan Police announced they would be reopening an investigation into Madeleines disappearance. A request for a review of the evidence came from then Home Secretary Theresa May.British polices involvement, known as Operation Grange, is led by the Specialist Crime Command Unit and directed by DCI Mark Cranwell, who has over  years experience in the force.The investigation has cost an estimated £million.In , Madeleine vanished from her bed in the McCanns holiday apartment in Rua Dr Agostinho da Silva, Praia da Luz.The ground-floor apartment was in the fth block of a group of apartments known as Waterside Village. At the time, Christian B, who is now German prosecutors lead suspect in the case, had been living at a run-down shack just miles away.Detectives have also focused on a small farmhouse in the hamlet of Monte Judeu, around four miles from Praia da Luz.This is where the suspect lived in the years before Madeleines disappearance.German prosecutors have said that the investigation in Christian B could be droppedthe public dont come forward with more information. Hans Christian Wolters told the BBC: #We have evidence against the accused which leads us to believe that he really killed Madeleine but this evidence is not strong enough at the moment to take him to court.#The investigator said that while the evidence is #strong enough to say that the girl is dead and strong enough to accuse a specic inidual of murder#, cops need more information from the public. He added: #One has to be honest and remain open to the possibility that our investigation could end without a charge, that it ends like the others have.#We are optimistic it will be dferent for us but for that we need more information.#It comes after Mr Wolters issued a plea for British tourists who lived in Praia da Luz between  and  to come forward.He told Sky News earlier: “We expect that she is dead, but we dont have enough evidence that we can get a warrant for our suspect in Germany for the murder of Madeleine McCann. Dutch police are working with German authorities to determine whether Christian B was behind the disappearance of a seven-year-old in .Police in The Hague said they were going to #exchange information# about the suspect with German cops, after Jaïr Soares vanished from a beach nearly  years ago.Leo Simais, from The Hagues cold case team, told Dutch paper De Telegraaf: #We would be crazywe didnt look closely at this German man.#We have now made contact with the German Criminal Investigation Service and are going to exchange information.#We are now working on a presentation about the disappearance of Jaïr, which we can then take with us#.A German police chief warned his officers to watch Christian B in , after he was released from prison for sexually abusing a child.The leading officer, from Braunschweig, where the suspect lived, reportedly told his officers #not to take eyes off him for a minute#.The now former cop told German newspaper Suddeutsche Zeitung: #Maybe we had the right feeling back then#.-year-old Christian B is currently serving a  month jail term for drugs trafficking. A BARMAID has recalled the moment Christian B shouted at her the child is dead when colleagues discussed Madeleine McCanns disappearance.The suspect is said to have got #very aggressive, nervous and agitated# as workers at a kiosk he ran in his hometown of Braunschweig brought up the toddler.Barmaid Lenta Johlitz, , told ITV News: #He said very loudly the child is dead! After all these years you wouldnt find such a corpse anyway.#That was the only situation where I look back and ask myself Why did he say that back then She previously revealed how Christian B #lost it# when the missing youngster was mentioned # and said it was a #good thing# she was dead.Lenta said: #He wanted us to stop. He cried out, ‘The child is dead now and that’s a good thing’, then he said: ‘You can make a body disappear quickly. Pigs also eat human flesh’.”A HOTEL receptionist’s slip let Christian B know Madeleine McCann would be alone in her holiday flat, sources alleged.They apparently noted a block dinner booking for parents Kate and Gerry and their “Tapas Seven” pals in an open staff register at Praia da Luz’s Ocean Club.A pal of sex predator Christian B who worked at the club is suspected to have seen the entry and told him when the McCann property would be easy to raid.But Portuguese lawyers say charging the pal with being an accomplice to the abduction would fail because it would be impossible to prove he meant to assist the crime.Lawyer Rui Pedro said: “The employee in question could only face disciplinary problems. And eventhere was intent, any crime they may have committed would now be spent.”MADELEINE McCann cops have no clue where her body is buried but do know how she was killed, it is claimed.Prosecutors in Germany say they have evidence the toddler was killed after she vanished in  in Praia da Luz but not enough to charge suspect Christian B.Speaking on Good Morning Britain, German newspaper Bild editor Julian Reichelt said: #They have an idea of how Madeleine McCann died # how the killing was actually done.#They do not know where the body for example may have been buried.#THE mum of a murdered nine-year-old schoolgirl dubbed the German Maddie was wrongly suspected of being involved in her abduction.Nine-year-old Peggy Knobloch disappeared in . Cops fear Christian B could be linked to her killing. Her remains were found in .Peggys mum Susanne Knobloch has reached out to Kate and Gerry McCann, who have also been ly accused about their daughter Madeleines disappearance.She said: #As parents, one has excessive hope again of finally getting answers to all questions. and most importantly, to get your child back.After the investigation into Christian B. was announced last week, Ms Knowloch said: #This not only clears them of suspicion, but also mentally.#HOPES of finding key forensic evidence to help charge Christian B. over Madeleines disappearance have been hit after it emerged  more people were in his van since he last used it.Cops are today probing newly unearthed satellite pictures of prime suspect Christian Bs van days after Madeleine vanished.A scrapyard owners son bought theVW T Westfalia campervan from Christian B in Portugal,Thereports.The son would drive pals and family around the Algarveand sleep in the vehicle. Cops seized it in .But Linda Brownlow,forensic science lecturer at the University of Greenwich told The : #DNA from those  people could itself be left behind over the top of Madeleine’s # thereby confusing her original profile.”SKY News has apologised after a video of Prince Andrew was accidentally shown during a clip about the Madeleine McCann prime suspect.During last nights broadcast, TV host Dermot Murnaghan introduced the bulletins top story about the investigation into Madeleines disappearance.He told viewers: #We have actual evidence Madeleine McCann is dead. German prosecutors reveal more on their investigation into the suspect, Christian B.#In the mix-up, Sky News then aired a video of Prince Andrew talking with another man who had his back to the camera.Read the full story here.PEGGY KNOBLOCH is the second child branded the #German Maddie# that has been linked to Christian B since he was revealed to be the prime suspect in Madeleines case.Last week, police in Germany confirmed they are re-investigating the paedo over the disappearance of five-year-old Inga Gehricke in May .Christian B has also been linked to the murder of a missing -year-old girl whose body was discovered on a beach in . Carola Titze had reportedly been in contact with a German man days before she disappeared while on holiday in De Haan in .And German detectives investigating Christian B have also contacted the family of missing René Hasee to say they were looking into his  abduction again.A RELATIVE of a former girlfriend of Christian B who was underage when they were together has urged her to speak to detectives.Her relationship with the main Madeleine McCann suspect started in, when she was .She hasnt been seen at her home in Braunschweig, where Christian B, , used to lived, since Friday.A relative said she fled the flat she shares with her mum after news broke last week about the police investigation into Christian B.He told the Daily Mail: #She needs to speak to police, she might know something # men tell their girlfriends things, they speak out when drunk # she could have information.#A WOMAN abducted and raped in the Algarve by a masked German man fears the attacker was Madeleine McCanns prime suspect.Hazel Behan, from Ireland, was working in Praia da Rocha # just a -minute drive from where the toddler vanished # when she was attacked.The victim, who waived her anonymity to the , was gagged and raped in her apartment in  but the culprit was never caught.She now fears Madeleine suspect Christian B could be her attacker as her ordeal bears chilling similarities to the Germans  rape on a -year-old American woman in Praia da Luz.Hazel said: #I thinkthe police had done their job investigating what happened to me,this is indeed the same man that attacked the American and abducted Madeleine McCann, they might have prevented the attack on her, and Madeleine would now be at home with her parents.”Read the full story here.THE image of Christian Bs campervan was captured days after three-year-old Madeleine went missing at the very start of the massive police search.His van had previously been parked at Praia do Barranco beach.A Portuguese investigating source said: “If that is the van in that spot # so soon after the abduction # the image could be extremely signicant.“He would have known that area well having lived there for six years but he had left the farmhouse months earlier.“So why did he go back at a time when everyone was looking for missing Madeleine ”Police investigating Madeleines disappearance are today probing newly unearthed satellite pictures of Christian Bs campervan # recorded days after she vanished.A Spanish investigator has spent days scouring old satellite imagery after the -year-old was last week identied as the prime suspect.And German police and Scotland Yard have now been sent a picture which could show the roof of the VW Westfalia T van parked near his former Praia da Luz home.The image could prove crucial because it suggests the distinctive van was taken back to open land Christian B was familiar with after living nearby for six years.Heres the full story.Businesswoman # and Sun columnist # Karren Brady says everyone who prayed for Madeleine to get home safely must now #pray for justice#.She said: #Today my heart is with the McCanns. #Their lives have been on hold since Madeleine disappeared. #An unbearable purgatory for them.#Heres the full story.Image: PAThis graphic shows the floor plan of the holiday flat in Portugal.Police were particularly interested in the window and the shutters of the apartment.Christian B allegedly went to burgle the McCann flat, where Madeleine was asleep close to younger twin brother and sister Sean and Amelie.But police suspect he was overcome by an impulse to snatch the three-old.WEVE blogged today about the dad of a Brit who vanished in Germany nearly  years ago.Trainee nurse Louise Kerton, , disappeared while visiting her boyfriend’s family.Her dad Phil,  and of Kent, has today pleaded with police to probe his daughters disappearance — saying evil Christian B targeted victims of all title: buy tesla autopilot dont use it
story: The weather was good and everything was normal . . . except for the truck on its side in the outside lane.We, the viewers, could see it. All the other drivers on the motorway could see it too. But the Tesla, bombing along at around mph, with its self-drive autopilot system engaged, did NOT see it.It even went straight past the driver of the overturned truck who was at the side of the road, a good distance from the crash site, frantically warning oncoming motorists to slow down. And then came the impact.Luckily, no one was hurt. But the accident does serve as a useful reminder about technology. It can make le fun and it can make le convenient. But we’ve not yet reached a point where we can rely on it to behave itself. Take the wi in your house.The box sits in a cupboard, I should imagine, where there’s no wind or rain or weather of any kind. It is never bashed or dropped. And yet somehow, once a fortnight, it will suddenly stop working. There is no reason for this.In my London flat, the windows also serve as radiators. They are designed to come on in October and go off again in April.But every year, they get it the wrong way round and no one is able to stop them doing this, boiling me in the summer and sitting there in the winter while I slowly die of hypothermia.My laptop is no better. The last one became critically ill recently, so before it died completely, all of its information was transferred on to the model I’m using now.And that, about once a day, decides to freeze. Control-Alt-Delete  Forget it. It becomes as receptive as a brick. We have all experienced these things. And we have to believe the owner of that Tesla in Taiwan has as well.Yet he engaged the car’s self-drive system and sat back, assuming it would be able to see a crashed van directly ahead. Had he not researched the car at all  I know Tesla says its autonomous system is nine times safer than a human. But a quick Google search would suggest that sometimes, like all technology, it isn’t safe at all.I actually quite like Tesla’s current range of cars. I think they are interesting and fun and I can see why, in lockdown, the Model  was the best-selling car in Britain. But I have a word of warning for anyone tempted to buy one and engage its autopilot: Don’t.Think of it as the tool you get on a Swiss Army kne that can be used for getting stones out of a horse’s hoof. It’s a talking point . . . but you’d never actually use it.IT has been the biggest police manhunt in history. But now, after a multimillion-pound, -year search across  countries, there appears to be a genuine breakthrough in the search for Madeleine McCann.That’s great. But what staggers me is that the new chief suspect Christian B was living just a few miles from the Portuguese resort where she was last seen. His phone puts him in the resort itself on the night of the abduction.He was even interviewed by Plod back in . And it’s not like he was a model citizen. Described as a burglar and a drug dealer, it’s known he was also a paedophile. He’s even doing time in Germany right now for child sex offences. And yet somehow he was never arrested.It makes me wonder. Will they find Lord Lucan living next door to the house from which he fled in  And will it turn out that “Mr Herring” who rides around Fulham every day on a horse called Shiregar is actually the mysterious Mr Kipper who is said to have abducted Suzy Lamplugh back in  THE Hungarian justice minister Judit Varga responded angrily this week to claims her country had become a dictatorship.I’m not sure what she said, though. Because apart from the fact she speaks four languages and is a lawyer, she is . . . well, let’s put it this way. She does to me what our Chancellor, Rishi Sunak, does for the girls.“I don’t care what you’re saying just so long as you keep on saying it.”At a rough guess, I’d say  per cent of everything on the internet is wrong.WHEN London was brought to its knees by a plague in the th century, a young man called Isaac Newton fled to the countryside and while in quarantine, came up with a cure.Recently unearthed papers show how he figured out the Black Death could be beaten with a medicine made from a powdered toad and some of its vomit.After it turned out this didn’t work, he went for a sit down in an orchard, where he saw an apple fall from a tree . . .THE the last-ever .-litre Bentley V rolled off the production line this week. Now, I know with race riots and coronavirus and the economy, this doesn’t sound like a big deal. But this engine was first used in , so it’s older than me. No other engine has been made for such a long time.In the beginning, it was used in the Bentley S – a car my grandfather drove – and produced hp. Today, the same basic engine in a Mulsanne produces hp. And yet emissions have come down by a scarcely believable  per cent.In the Fties, it was the last word in silent power. And that holds true today. It’s a gentleman giant of a thing and we shall not see its like again.Sure, the motor in a modern electric car is very quiet and powerful too. But it’s the same sort of thing you get in a Magimix. Whereas Bentley’s old V  The same sort of thing you got in a Spitfire.SO, to be clear,you go to Parliament Square in a group of about ,, the police will take a knee as a mark of respect. If, however, you go to the pub with a few mates for a couple of pints, you and the man who served you will be arrested.In other news, you can go to Spain for your summer holiday but you can’t come back. Or maybe you can’t go at all. Or maybe you can . . . but onlyyou have one other travelling companion and you have a barbecue first.It’s no wonder we fear the Covid death rate will inch back up. None of us has the first clue what’s allowed any more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: But now he urgently needs to turbo-charge business as the economy teeters on the edge of a catastrophic nosee.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThe Chancellor is drawing up a package of measures. A top priority must be a leline to the ailing car industry.This bedrock of engineering is worth £billion a year to the nation’s finances.But its collapse has already cost the economy £billion this year, putting , jobs at risk.A dismal  new cars have been built since the start of the pandemic and there is also uncertainty about Nissan’s Sunderland plant.So a revival of the car scrappage scheme is a good place to start. But it must not only apply to electric cars.Costly e-cars are out of the reach of most pockets, and charging points are thin on the ground.Rishi should make sure there is money off any new motor.Evenonly for a short time, it would give manufacturers the bump start they need.The Chancellor has a massive to-do list.But the economy won’t get out of first gearBritain doesn’t get motoring.RESTRICTIVE Sunday trading laws should be abolished.So it is encouraging to hear that Downing Street is planning to suspend them to allow bigger stores to stay open longer. The Sun on Sunday has long argued the laws are past their sell-by date but with all churches closed in the present crisis it is even more ludicrous.Many front-line heroes such as nurses can only do their weekly shop on Sundays when queues can stretch round the block.And in this economic crisis big stores are losing much needed trade.Predictably, Labour and the unions have opposed the plan.Why don’t they think about the public for a change ONE of the astonishing things to come out of the Madeleine McCann story is the fact that in Germany a convicted criminal’s identity must remain secret.In crucial appeals for information, German police can only refer to the paedophile and convicted rapist as “Christian B”.In Britain the fact of an arrest is now considered private too. title: prince andrew report authorities
story: Ministers and officials have a duty to protect the Monarchy.Butthey refuse to hand the Prince over to the US authorities for questioning, it will look as though they are hampering an important criminal investigation and denying justice for Epstein’s many victims.Which is why Prince Andrew must report to the authorities and give the fullest, frankest statement he can muster.We know he’d rather bury his head in the sand.But the longer he stays silent, the worse the situation will get.Angry American investigators are fed up with his lack of cooperation already and have no plans to let him off the hook.Though the Prince has issued emphatic denials of wrongdoing, the very fact we have got to the point where the US is having to make back-channel requests to the Home Office in a criminal case shows just how badly the Queen’s favourite son has played this.Let’s hope he finds the guts to face up to his responsibilities — and fast.WHEN the inevitable inquiry is held into Britain’s handling of the Coronavirus pandemic, we hope Public Health England and SAGE are brought to the dock first.We know that politicians are the ultimate decision makers, so the finger of blame can’t be pointed solely at scientists.But from where we’re standing it looks like these territorial and well-funded quangos have rather a lot to answer for.PHE failed to build stocks of personal protective equipment, was against German-style mass testing and dragged its feet over sourcing ventilators.And now a top SAGE scientist has done a whopping U-turn on lockdown.John Edmunds, who claimed in mid March that herd immunity was the solution, said yesterday that he wishes Britain had shut up earlier.The Prime Minister must show leadership and reform these crumbling institutions before the public loses trust.THE hardline EU states blocking Michel Barnier from making compromises must get a grip before it’s too late.With Boris Johnson and his Vote Leave gang at the heart of government, Britain will happily walk away from talksthey don’t prove fruitful.And it will be EU leaders — already dealing with the fallout from lockdown — facing the music of a no deal Brexit at the ballot box.The UK is asking for a fair deal from the EU — hardly dferent to that which has been agreed by Canada or Japan.It’s time stubborn European politicians swallowed their pride. Our journalists strive title: trevor kavanagh boris public health bureaucrats
story: Boris Johnson is ready to reopen the pubs, restaurants and hairdressers that make ordinary le worth living by the end of this month or early July.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesHe plans a Save Our Summer campaign to salvage a crippled travel and leisure industry worth more than £billion — and the .million jobs that go with it.Months of self-isolation, closed shops and shuttered town centres may be nearly over.The PM is responding to dismay within his own ranks over the shambolic quarantine on air travellers, compulsory face masks and the absurd two-metre distancing rule.His focus sharpened last week when told about the likely jobs meltdown.“Christ!” he responded, and ordered a swt shake-up to the timetable for le to begin again.The PM is personally in tune with those who want rules relaxed.But he has been hemmed in by the same bumbling public-health bureaucrats who landed us with the worst Covid death toll in Europe and put the skids under the British economy.They include “Bonking Boffin” Professor Neil Ferguson, who triggered panic with alarmist predictions of , Covid corpses.But the key culprits are Public Health England, the quango whose sole responsibility is keeping us safe.Instead, they reacted like rabbits paralysed in the head-lights when the coronavirus burst out of Wuhan.Boris won’t put it like that when he addresses the nation with his plan of attack in the next week or two.But despite stern opposition from some scientic experts, he has decided the battle against the virus must be fought alongside, not after, the fight to save the health, wealth and prosperity of the nation.Track-and-trace plans will proceed at top speed, along with the search for a vaccine.The NHS will not drop its guard.But the PM is acutely aware of alarm among Tories over government floundering.“It goes from bad to worse,” said one loyalist minister. “We are looking confused. “The two-week quarantine rule is bonkers and so is the rule on face masks. “We may be popular in the polls, but governments are meant to lead public opinion, not follow.”Senior ministers, led by Chancellor Rishi Sunak, warn that each day lost before reopening Britain for business marks another swathe of jobs gone — some for ever.Mass unemployment, unseen since the Great Depression in the s, would devastate the Red Wall voters in the North and Midlands who put Boris into power.So the resumption of normal le has been brought forward by weeks.First to go will be the two-metre rule — already abandoned in reality on beaches, in parks and on Whitehall, where Black Lives Matter protesters hug each other.Strict social-distancing measures make bus and Tube travel virtually impossible. Boris wants distancing cut to one metre, giving the all-clear for pubs and restaurants to reopen and start rehiring the millions laid off since lockdown.Rishi Sunak is counting on this to trim Treasury job-support measures costing the economy a dizzying £billion.It will kickstart a new-normal summer, with open-air weddings, beer-garden service and marquees to protect punters from the rain.Summer holidays are back on track after being stymied for weeks.Airlines will bypass quarantine with air corridors to approved holiday destinations such as Italy, France, Greece and Turkey.These measures are not risk-free. Scientists point to a possible surge in Covid cases in the North.But equally reputable experts insist there is little chance of a second wave.The risk of the NHS failing to cope has now passed.Meanwhile, lockdown has brought its own death toll. Countless lives have certainly been lost from failure to diagnose and treat cancers and heart diseases.The price in lost schooling and crippled le chances will be paid for decades to come.Lting lockdown is a tough decision for any prime minister.But, as Boris knows better than most, to lead is to choose. It’s what he was elected for.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: eastenders new tarzan speak was for the hard of thinking
story: THESE last three months, it’s seemed like only two places on Earth have avoided being trapped in lockdown.Sweden and EastEnders.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesAnd I don’t know what state of paranoid despair the Scandinavians have been enduring but I would still take my chances pub crawling in downtown Malmo before I set foot in Walford, where the only acknowledgement of the coronavirus outbreak has been a practical one.To drag out the torture, it’s now only on twice a week. A delaying-the-inevitable tactic which meant, by the time Phil and Dennis’s tickets for the April  game between West Ham and Burnley arrived in mid May, the fixture was as dead as Dennis.A lucky escapeyou ask me.The day of reckoning, when it runs out of episodes, fast approaches, of course. For the duration of the outbreak, though, it’s been a biological miracle.Regulars have packed The Vic, mobbed the Bridge Street market and just stood around gawping and muttering, in their usual community-serving way, when Keegan’s sandwich van was trashed by the local drug dealers.The presence of a global pandemic hasn’t stopped EastEnders lecturing us about other medical issues, obviously.Since the boat party accident, in February, it’s been particularly concerned about Ben Mitchell’s deafness, which cut no ice with me for a couple of good reasons.Firstly, Ben Mitchell is a dreadful, immoral, six-headed little turd who it’s impossible to like, let alone love.Secondly, they’d forgotten he was partially deaf for most of the previous decade.There’s not an international crisis or continuity glitch in the universe that can stand in the way of EastEnders’ moral grandstanding, though, so they decided viewers should “see and hear” last week’s heist episode, with Barry Grant off Brookside, through the eyes and ears of Ben.A particularly gormless enterprise, this one, which went off like Norman Collier and Jimi Hendrix on the same bill at The Half Moon in Putney, and was all feedback and missing words.To ram home the message for the hard of thinking, the action was also accompanied by word cloud subtitles that appeared to have been written by Tarzan.“Keep mind on job.”“Cut power.”“Ben, this mistake.”“Daughter without father.”Compared with other EastEnders episodes, I enjoyed it a lot. I usually do when the show tries something a bit dferent and thought you could actually write the entire history of the show in half a dozen lines of this new Tarzan-speak.“Den hate Angie.” “Peter change head.” “Phil. Him shot.” “You not mother.” “Me am mother.” “Peter change head again.” “Get out pub.” It’d be timely as well. After  years and four months of almost constant shouting and stall-minding, EastEnders goes off air next week.Tantalisingly, The Sun’s very own Andy Halls reported, on Friday, that when it s the show will have dropped its old storylines. A dream scenario which allowed me to fantasise about EastEnders .. A happier, funnier show that’s only on twice a week, where the BBC doesn’t endlessly bask in its own right-on virtue and the majority of characters actually sound like Londoners, instead of stage-schooleditorials.But that’s not going to happen, is it So I’m just going to enjoy the silence. Tarzan like.TIPPING Point, Ben Shephard: “Which city in the Midlands shares its name with a meeting between two sporting rivals ”Bill: “Birmingham.”Celebrity Mastermind, John Humphrys: “In an th century poem, what season of the year did Keats describe as ‘a season of mists and mellow fruitfulness’ ”Monty Panesar: “Oliver Twist.”Ben Shephard: “The Anglo-Dutch wars were fought primarily between England and which modern-day country ”Amy: “Denmark.”.THE Last Leg, Desiree Burch on the George Floyd fallout: “Follow black artists and thinkers on social media, people who have good resources, information, opinions and insights. Right now I have two shows you could watch — Desiree’s Coming Early and Tar Baby.”Or you could watch Too Hot To Handle, where Netflix films young people having sex while artist thinker Desiree offers her “insights and opinions”.But she’s clearly too modest to mention her role on that one.THIS week’s winner is Tory MP Andrew Bridgen and Harry Enfield’s Tim Nice But Dim. Sent in by RJ.FIRST job for the Beeb’s new Director General, Tim Davie  Find out how Peter Crouch: Save Our Summer ended up on primetime, Saturday night, BBC. Seriously, how  It’s a late-night ITV show, with no one to bleep out the swearing, but with BBC levels of over-manning.The star, obviously, was Peter Crouch, who’s actually funnier than  per cent of TV comedians and more likable than all of them, but not yet ready to front his own show. So they added Maya Jama, who looked sensational in her Status Quo Blue For You-era denims, the compulsory Horne Section and Chris Ramsey, who was hiding behind a fence at the start. And should’ve stayed there. All deserve our sympathy. SOS was meant to be a Euro  spin-off and when the tournament vanished so did the show’s point. Camera angles also seem to have gone to hell, but that’s maybe an act of socially distanced mercy given what’s happening front and centre.Saturday’s content included: A teabag- flipping contest between Mo Farah and Ellie Simmonds, parachuting with Jermaine Jenas, which was straight off the Alan Partridge script and foul-mouthed football “bantz” from Rio Ferdinand, who said his career was ended by Peter Crouch, so may have been playing keepy-uppy to the Match Of The Day theme tune as some sort of twisted payback.The really alarming thing, though, is the series lasts eight weeks.Save Our Summer  At this rate, there’ll be a dark cloud hanging over autumn as well.For the record, it was the BBC News.SPRINGWATCH’s Steve Backshall wearing a “No planet B” T-shirt like he’s a -year-old student, rather than a -year-old BBC presenter who won’t shut up about his three kids. Bafta giving nominations to The Greatest Dancer and The Ranganation but not a Best Drama nod to Line Of Duty.This Morning’s Phillip Schofield losing his very short temper with John Torode over yoghurt dressing. Anyone who says “chowing down” instead of eating. And the clearly smitten GMB host Susanna Reid making an involuntary groping gesturewith her left hand, just after she says the name Keir Starmer. Easy tiger.PETER Crouch: “It wasn’t all about improving, it was also about getting better.”Ian Wright: “The one thing about Gerrard was his professionalism and the fact he was so versatile.”Paul Merson: “It was definitely half an open goal.”                                 SKY Documentaries’ McMillion, the best show on TV.Ralph’s wedding on The A Word. ITV’s th birthday tribute to the great Bradley Walsh.The GMB spat between Piers Morgan and Donald Trump’s lawyer, Rudy Giuliani, which had everything except the obvious reprimand: “Rudy. Stop your messin’ around.”And Channel ’s Murder In The Outback, where disgraced Australian lawyer Andrew Fraser proves, beyond much forensic doubt, Bradley Murdoch did indeed kill Peter Falconio.The only slight glitch being, he’s trying to prove the exact opposite.Watch it, Channel , tonight and tomorrow, pm. The self-delusion becomes hypnotic. A Gillian Burke on Springwatch B Connell Waldron on Normal People C Comedian Tom Allen on nearly everything MOST surprising thing about Britain’s Best Parent  Anita Rani isn’t the most annoying person on this Channel  show.In fact, she’s not even close to a medal position thanks to the other five – two couples and a single mum – who must champion their own style of parenting, whether  it’s “pushy” or “vegan” or mollycoddling or just sort of lying around in bed all day treating their offspring as the hired help.Like the rest of us, Channel  silently understands, of course, listening to strangers talk about their small children is no more engaging or enlightening than listening to a ­scientologist talk about L. Ron Hubbard, so they’ve included a few eccentrics to liven  up the process.On the one hand there’s martial arts enthusiast Robin, who explains: “Our parenting style is influenced by eastern philosophy. Buddhism, Taoism, Confucianism,” ventriloquism, egotism, Roxette’s fourth album Tourism.On the other there’s gender fluid feminist nut Joana, who is attempting to bring up five-year-old son Willow as “a free spirit”, by banning the word “boy”, refusing to buy him “militaristic toys” and plastering her house in idiotic Socialist Worker propaganda.Hopefully, little Willow will be a stalwart of his local golf club and TA unit  in about  years’ time.But that’s no real saving grace for the show, nor a reason to watch any part of Britain’s Best Parent, apart from the final vote where, every week, the studio audience has to choose between those “free spirits” who let the kids rule the roost and those couples, like David and Nicky, who run their house more like an SAS boot camp.And every week, I’m happy to report, they vote for the boot camp.All hope for Britain may not be lost.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: madeleine mccann new image campervan
story: A Spanish investigator has spent days scouring old satellite imagery after the -year-old serial child sex beast was identied last week.And German police and Scotland Yard have now been sent a picture which could show the roof of the VW Westfalia T van parked near his former Praia da Luz home.The image could prove crucial because it suggests the distinctive van was taken back to open land Christian B was familiar with after living close-by for six years.But it raises questions over why Christian B ed to the farmhouse just days after Madeleine vanished when he was living in the campervan, not the run-down home.Imagery shows the white roof of a van of similar dimensions to the VW parked beside a hedge yards from a ramshackle single-storey former farmhouse plot.He lived there with a German lover from  to , when he did a runner and left the building strewn with debris including wigs and smashed computer gear.But the picture shows the van appears to have been driven back to the plot - which is surrounded by scrubland littered with deep, abandoned well shafts.One of the old stone wells is visible a few feet from the van.The image was captured days after three-year-old Madeleine went missing at the very start of the massive police search.A Portuguese investigating source said last night: “If that is the van in that spot - so soon after the abduction - the image could be extremely signicant.“He would have known that area well having lived there for six years but he had left the farmhouse months earlier.“So why did he go back at a time when everyone was looking for missing Madeleine ”Christian B, now , split with his German partner after tempestuous rows at the ramshackle farmhouse.In June , Scotland Yard detectives - backed by a team of cadaver dogs and ground penetrating radar - excavated land  yards from the building but unearthed no clues.But their focus was on ground closer to the main road and it is not clearthey checked the many wells dotted around the landscape.The beauty spot is also well known to Madeleines parents Kate and Gerry, who regularly jogged around Black Rock after launching the hunt for their daughter in Praia da Luz in May .Cops are now preparing to dig up land around two Portuguese lairs where he lived.Locals - who described Christian B as a “quiet, angry weirdo” - say he would have known the area well and believe vital evidence may have been missed.Spanish investigator Heriberto Janosch Gonzálezfound discovered the picture during a trawl of satellite records last week.He said: “For the last five days I was looking for evidence concerning the houses and vehicles belonging to Madeleine McCanns crime new suspect Christian B, following Scotland Yard Operation Grange and German Bundeskriminalmatappeals.“I found a NASA satellite photograph taken days after the abduction of Madeleine.“It shows one of the houses where he lived, and an image totally congruent with the dimensions and colour of the VW Westfalia van that the suspect were using at that time.“I have passed this information to Operation Grange and German Bundeskriminalmatyesterday .“If he is involved in Madeleine McCann abduction, as the police appeals suggested, maybe he carried her to that place, and some evidence or her remains were hidden in that location.“Will the police search that house and the field around, including the wells ”Police in Germany fear the drter, who stole from hotels in Praia da Luz, may have snatched Madeleine after first entering the holiday home to raid it.Among the growing body of facts linking him to Madeleines disappearance is he was revealed to be living in a campervan in the area around the time the youngster vanished on May , .As well as the campervan, the drug dealer and burglar also been linked to a  Jaguar XJR with a German number plate seen in Praia da Luz and surrounding areas in  and .On May ,  - the day after Madeleine vanished - he got the Jaguar re-registered in Germany under someone s name although it is believed the vehicle remained in Portugal.German police believe one of the two vehicles were used in the disappearance of Madeleine.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: builder metal rod stuck up bum
story: The -year-old labourer was working on a building site in Bangkok, Thailand when he fell onto the steel pole and will be sore for several weeks.Teerawat Choeyku was working to repair the roof of the building when strong winds hit on June .He mistakenly stepped onto old roof tiles amid the chaos - and they broke.He then plunged onto the ground below and landed on a ft long metal rod, which went straight up his backside.Eye-watering pictures show how the metal penetrated his body before emerging in his lower back.The steel pole that inserted into his rectum can be seen pressing against the skin in Teerawats lumber region.Shocked colleagues at the construction site called emergency services who arrived to find Teerawat in agony as he lay on the ground.Firemen cut off about .ft of the stick protruding from his bottom on site.They were then able to transport him to a nearby hospital.Teerawats friend, Apichai, said: He was fixing the broken roof that was hit by the heavy storm from the last few weeks.“He stepped onto the old roof tiles. They cracked and he fell down.Teerawat is being treated in hospital and is in a stable condition, expected to make a full recovery.Rescue worker Jakchai Banyensakul from the Ruamkatanyu Foundation said Teerawat was lucky to survive.Jakchai said: The young man is lucky to have survived this as the pole could have caused much worse damage.”He added his wounds will be “sore for several weeks” but he will recover.Jakchai said safety at work is especially important on construction sites when there is wet and windy weather, and he hopes people hear Teerawat’s story and are reminded to be careful.Teerawat’s unfortunate slip is the latest in a string of incidents that have seen construction workers suffer similar injuries.In November last year, a builder in China was impaled by a metal rod that went up his backside and narrowly missed his heart after falling from a construction .The unnamed -year-old was working on a building site in the city of Huzhou in eastern China when he fell almost  feet onto the rebar.He fell unconscious and was rushed to the nearby Zhejiang University No  Hospital, where he underwent emergency surgery.Doctors said the bar went through several internal organs, with a D x-ray of the man showing the path it travelled after entering his body.The tip of the bar stopped just three centimetres short of the mans heart.The emergency procedure required several doctors, including specialists in the liver and intestine responsible for removing the bar from each organ.The bar was finally removed at around am on the day following the accident.In April last year, a -year-old man on a site in the northeastern city of Jinan fell ft onto a bar that entered his backside and came out the side of his head.And in , another -year-old working in the Liaoning Province fell onto a bar that went in through the back of his neck and came out through his mouth.

story: Non-essential retail will begin to open back up from next week as the Government tries to get Britains businesses up and running after months of shut down.Brits will be able to start shopping again and donating their clothes to charity stores after months of lockdown sort-outs.The move is part of the Governments efforts to kickstart Britains economy after most shops and businesses have been forced to keep their doors closed since March .Alok Sharma said this evening: Now thanks to the efforts of the British people we have succeeded in reducing the number of infections and getting the R rateunder control. That is why we can carefully begin to open parts of economy in a phased and careful manner.I can confirm today that retail outlets which have been required to close will be able to open their doors again from Monday June , so long as they comply with the Covid secure guidelines This is the latest step in the careful restarting of our economy and will enable high streets up and down the country to spring back to le.The Government has said the R rate is between . and . but fears have grown it could have tipped over  in some areas of the UK. If it goes past  the virus could start to spread again with warp speed and cause a dreaded second peak in Britain.Businesses will need to complete a COVID- risk assessment before opening and will need to display a notice in their windows declaring they have put steps in place to stop the spread of the virus.Customers will have to follow strict social distancing rules and shops will have to limit the number of people allowed in - title: north korea severs contact south phones kim jong un hiding
story: The move follows Kim Jong-uns emergence from hiding after weeks out of the public eye and widespread speculation about his health. A report on the state-run Korean Central News Agencysaid that the North would shut off all communication from midday today. In the absence of formal diplomatic relations or embassies, the two countries typically communicate via a jointly-run body called the Inter-Korean Liaison Office. The office maintains a number of lines of communication, including hotlines between senior figures within the countries militaries as well as their presidential offices. The North has released a series of statements over the last week threatening to close the officethe South did not stop defectors sending anti-regime material back over the border. Defectors from North Korea are known to use a number of methods, including pamphlets dropped from small air balloons, to get information back into the country. The move is likely also part of diplomatic manoeuvring related to severe international sanctions currently in place on the North, the Times reported. The sanctions are thought to be having a devastating impact on North Koreas economy and population. Despite the decision only officially coming into force today, a spokesperson for the South Korean ministry of defence said routine daily calls made through the liaison office yesterday went unanswered. Daniel Wertz, Programme Manager at the National Committee on North Korea, tweeted that severing communications was a well-worn play for the North, but a dangerous one amid the coronavirus crisis. The spat comes after Kim Jong-un disappeared from view for almost three weeks in April, prompting speculation about his health as well as reports of his death. He reemerged at the beginning of May, and this week was seen smiling at a meeting of senior officials from the ruling Workers Party.The KNCA report stated that Kim and other senior figures in Pyongyang had decided that “the work towards the South should thoroughly turn into one against an enemy”.“[The North Korean people have] been angered by the treacherous and cunning behaviour of the South Korean authorities, with whom we will have lots of accounts to settle, it said. “We have reached a conclusion that there is no need to sit face to face with the South Korean authorities and there is no issue to discuss with them, as they have only aroused our dismay.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. But its not guaranteed they will all go back before the holidays.From June , kids in years ten and  - or those in college with exams next year - will be able to have some contact time with their teachers.This will be to discuss their learning at home and talk about how to improve and get ready for next years exams.Gavin Williamson confirmed today the Government does plan on having exams next year - including A Levels, GCSEs, BTECs and others.But the remainder of secondary school pupils will be expected to carry on learning at home until September.The Government is looking into this at the moment.While schools wont be able to open their doors to everyone, ministers are looking at drawing up a priority list for people who need to get back to work.Parents who cant stay at home with their little one or where there is one child in school but the other is not, may be offered a school slot.More details are expected on this in the coming weeks, but it will be up to your schoolthey will be able to provide the space for your child.At the moment the Government are making plans for summer camps for kids who really need the extra help to catch up.Its likely that they will fund classes over the summer, where kids can attend.But it wont be for all pupils, and its not yet known who will run them.The Department for Education are also dishing out laptops to needy kids to make sure they can still learn while theyre at home. In Wales, the Government plans to reopen all schools on June , with a third of children at most in school at any time.And in Scotland kids willto classrooms from August, but with only half their time at school and the rest at home.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: prince andrew never cooperate jeffrey epstein
story: Sources have reportedly claimed Prince Andrew will not get behind the investigation as he believes US attorney Geoffrey Berman wants to make an example of him.Insiders said Prince Andrew would have already fully cooperatednot for the aggressive actions of the US attorney in pursuing him.The Duke of Yorks team reportedly fear the lawyer wants to turn him into a scapegoat for the failures of the case - and sources said its now impossible for him to cooperate.It comes amid a back and forth between Andrews team and Mr Berman as the Royal insisted he had offered to assist in the investigation three times. Mr Berman however issued a statement which accused the Prince of ly portraying himself to the public as eager and willing to co-operate. The US Department of Justice has filed a mutual legal assistance request to the Home Office - which formally asks for help to question the Royal.Andrew is facing ongoing scrutiny over his links to convicted sex offender Epstein, who was at the centre of a web of sex trafficking and abuse before killing himself in jail last August.The Duke has always denied any improper behaviour over his relationship with Epstein, and strongly denies allegations he slept with sex slave Virginia Roberts when she was .Sources have claimed Andrew may never cooperate with the probe while Mr Berman is in charge, reports the " href"https:www.telegraph news    epstein-prosecutor-has-made-impossible-prince-andrew-co-operate " target"_blank" rel"noreferrer noopener". Insiders insist that Andrew should remain a witness rather than a target in the federal investigation into Epstein.The source said: The Duke would have cooperated fully with Berman had he not chosen to make an example of him.What we saw yesterday was a trebling down by Berman on this consistent modus operandi of throwing away the rule book and commenting on what are supposed to be completely confidential discussions surrounding the co-operation of a witness.The source added: Why does he get to tear the rule book up  Who does he think he is  There is no way that statement was designed to encourage the Duke to co-operate. It was a sarcastic, knee-jerk response to a very reasonable and factually accurate statement about the assistance the Duke has offered so far. In fact, all it does is confirm what we have been dealing with here all along.Royal insiders accused Mr Berman of seeking publicity and attempting to use Andrew as a scapegoat for the failures of the case.Andrew is claimed to have been first contacted by authorities in January, despite Epstein being investigated for  years. Mr Berman previously claimed the Duke has offered zero cooperation back in January, and then said the Royal had completely shut the door on the probe in March.The source said: Every time Berman has opened his mouth, he has undermined his own case.Lawyers for the Duke of York, , have insisted he has offered to give a witness statement to investigators probing Epstein.Mr Berman, the US Attorney for the Southern District of New York, has accused Andrew of repeatedly refusing to cooperate - and alleges the Dukes team unequivocally told his office in March he would not be quizzed.Lawyer Gloria Allred, who represents some of Epsteins victims, told BBCs Newsnight: Justice delayed is justice denied and he needs to stop playing a cat and mouse game with the United States Department of Justice.He needs to stop delaying and trying to evade answering questions and he should not be setting any conditions,in fact thats what hes doing.It comes as William Barr, the US Attorney General, said the Duke of York will not be extradited to the US for questioning over his links into Epstein.Andrews legal firm also hit out at earlier claims from Mr Berman that there has been a wall of silence from the Duke.Blackfords LLP acting for the royal said: The Duke of York has on at least three occasions this year offered his assistance as a witness to the DOJ. Unfortunately, the DOJ has reacted to the first two offers by breaching their own confidentiality rules and claiming that the Duke has offered zero cooperation.In doing so, they are perhaps seeking publicity rather than accepting the assistance proffered.The Sun Online has contacted Andrews lawyers for comment.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: school kids might not be back september
story: The admission came as ministers confirmed they have scrapped a pledge to get all primary kids back in for a month before summer.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesFurious MPs and campaigners said the reopening of pubs and theme parks are being prioritised over childrens le chances.They called for a “national crusade” to create new ‘Nightingale schools’ in village halls and churches to get kids learning again.A government source said they expect schools to reopen for “more pupils” by September but are taking a “cautious approach”.They added: “It is dficult for me to predict what is going to happen in the coming weeks and what the scientic advice is going to be.”Education Secretary Gavin Williamson told MPs he hopes all kids will get back to class September – but fell short of promising to.He said: “While we are not able to welcome all primary children back for a full month before the summer, we continue to work with the sector on the next steps.“We would like to see schools who have the capacity to bring back more children in those smaller class sizes.“We will be working to bring all children back to school in September.”His words left the door open to only bringing kids back to school part time, with remote home learning carrying on.It came as:Primary schools began reopening for nursery, reception and Years One and Six last week.But they have been told to bring in social distancing and cap their classes at  to protect their pupils from Covid.This means heads will need twice as many classrooms and teachers to get all their pupils back in full time.Downing Street scaled back their targets after admitting many schools simply do not have the space to do this.Quizzed in the Commons today, Mr Williamson said he was desperate to ensure “there is not a generation of children who miss out” in the schools shutdown.But in a hint a big dose of homeschooling is here to stay, he said a new “basic minimum curriculum” for remote teaching is being drawn up.While he suggested schools may only be able toto full capacity when the protective bubble system is no longer needed.He said: “We do have limitations – where we have a limit of  children per class that obviously does limit the ability to have as many year groups in school as we like.“But as this is changed and as this is modied, this will give us the ability to slowly and cautiously move forward in terms of welcoming more children back to school when that is the right time.”Mr Williamson suggested it may take over a year for kids to catch up on their studies.And he said the Government is working on an “ambitious” plan which will give children extra support.But ministers faced a furious backlash over their plans.The Children’s Commissioner warned a massive “educational gap” is being created by keeping schools shut for many kids.Anne Longfield said: “Look at some of the things the Government has prioritised over recent months at vast scale and speed - the measures to save jobs, the ,-bed hospitals, propping up the economy. All of those things have happened in a way that is unimaginable.Its that level of will and determination that’s needed.”She warned that kids’ lives risk being “furloughed” unless action is taken urgently.She fumed: Were seeing a situation where theme parks are going to be open in a months time, shops, pubs and restaurants but still children are not back in school.Tory MP and education select committee boss Robert Halfon said it is a “strange country” that allows mass protests to erupt and campaigns for pubs to reopen while kids are still barred from going to school.Steve Chalke, head of the Oasis academy schools chain, told The Sun there needs to be a “national crusade” to find community spaces to teach kids in.He said: “I am saying to community leaders – give us your halls, give us your hotel lobbies, your church halls, mosque halls – the spaces big enough for a bubble. Give us those.“They are stood there empty, doing nothing. We can use those spaces to teach kids.”He said it was predictable the “wheels would come off” the government’s policy because it has not been thought through.He said: “The government said schools need to be socially distanced and then said the whole school has got to come back.“You don’t have to be Einstein to work out that is impossible. There is no school in the whole world able to take back its entire cohort and maintain social distancing.”To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: labour leader keir starmer takes a knee george floyd
story: He was pictured alongside his deputy Angela Rayner, and said on Twitter: We kneel with all those opposing anti-Black racism #BlackLivesMatter”.The phrase take a knee is a protest against the unfair treatment of Black Americans, coming from an American football play.The poignant stance has been adopted by the Black Lives Matter movement and has swept the world in recent protests.Sir Keir shared a picture ‘taking a knee’ this afternoon as demonstrators met in Parliament Square to mark George Floyd’s funeral.Despite coronavirus fears, tens of thousands have protested in the wake of Floyd’s death in Minneapolis police custody, after officer Derek Chauvin pressed his knee into the handcuffed African-American’s neck for nearly nine minutes despite Floyd’s cries of “I can’t breathe”.Parliament came to a halt at am for a minutes silence in memory of Floyd, with Sir Keir addressing his murder afterwards.The Labour leader said: “He must not become just another name. His death must be a catalyst for change.”The official Downing Street spokesperson revealed that the prime minister and his cabinet did not take part in the minute’s silence.Boris Johnson reportedly told ministers there is “so much more to do in eradicating prejudice and creating opportunity”.The spokesperson said: “The PM began Cabinet by discussing the anger and the grief that is not just felt in the US but around the world including the UK following the death of George Floyd.”“He said those who lead and govern simply cannot ignore the depth of emotion that has been triggered.”“The PM said there was an undeniable feeling of injustice and that people from black and minority ethnic groups do face discrimination in education, in employment and in the application of criminal law.“The PM said we’re a much, much less racist society than we were but we must also frankly acknowledge that there’s so much more to do in eradicating prejudice and creating opportunity.”Last night, Boris Johnson sent a message to the UK, saying the Black Lives Matter protesters cannot be ignored but rioters must face the full force of the law.In a Twitter video message last night, he acknowledged the concerns of anti-racist protesters are founded on a cold reality.However, he warned there would be consequences to those who damage property or harm the police.Mr Johnson added he would not support those who break social distancing rules.The Met Police said they arrested  people over the weekend and added dozens of officers suffered injuries.

title: thousands cops english force obese overweight
story: Chief Superintendent Lucy Hutson, of Hampshire Constabulary, said almost  per cent of her force are fat.She raised concerns at the “risk” level of the majority of her officers in a recent email.The revelation follows a voluntary health screening project carried out by the force with  of its officers and staff.In her email to the constabulary, Supt Hutson, who has  years’ police experience, said: “Our health screening programme indicates that almost  per cent of the force is currently overweight or obese.”The force claimed the figures were in line with national obesity statistics and could be skewed as muscle is heavier than fat — so could mean some cops are just beefier.And a spokeswoman said officers had shed pounds since the survey anyway.The spokeswoman said Supt Hutson had worked off figures from “a few weeks ago” which showed  per cent of the force was obese — but the figure has now fallen to  per cent.She added: “In terms of body fat percentage only  per cent came out as obese, showing there is a lot of lean body massin the constabulary.”Being obese doubles the risk of needing hospital treatment for coronavirus and is linked to ­developing heart problems and type  diabetes, research shows.Annual fitness tests became compulsory for all police officers in England and Wales in .GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: She also told how she asked himhe snatched " rel"noreferrer noopener"Madeleine McCann — and he warned: “Just don’t go there.”The woman is one of two British former girlfriends of " href"https:www.thesun news  madeleine-mccann-latest-news-update " target"_blank" rel"noreferrer noopener"child sex offender Christian who were dating him while he was in the Praia da Luz area of Portugal and have now given evidence to police.Both live in fear of the German drug dealer, who beat them up, and have asked not to be identied.One has told of a chilling conversation she had with Christian over dinner on May ,  — " rel"noreferrer noopener"the night before Madeleine, three, was abducted from her parents’ apartment in the Portuguese resort. You won’t be seeing me for a while.”Christian disappeared at the same time as Madeleine — resurfacing three years later working in a bar in Lagos, around six miles from Praia da Luz.It was in the bar in  that his other British girlfriend suggested " rel"noreferrer noopener"he was a dead ringer for some of the photofits of the Madeleine suspects — and jokingly asked: “You did it Christian, didn’t you ”A friend of the girls said today: “He blanked the question and shrugged — then added, ‘Just don’t go there’.”The pal added: “It was said at a time when everyone had a theory about the Madeleine mystery and everyone had a story.So everyone who knew him around that time kind of dismissed it.”Christians cryptic comments the night before Madeleine vanished were similarly not taken seriously at the time.The friend added: “The ex-girlfriend with him at dinner didn’t compute what he’d said because she didn’t believe him capable of doing something like that — " rel"noreferrer noopener"even though he had been violent before.“Then Christian went off the radar the day after the abduction. title: 2m rule slashed infections come down
story: Sarah Albon suggested it wasnt just about the distance away from another person which was important to consider, it was about the chances of getting it too.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThe more the virus is circulating around, the more of a risk it will be to go within than two metres from someone.MPs and campaigners have been lobbying to cut the m rule down to save thousands of businesses and jobs.Businesses fear that having to stay so far apart will cripple them, as they will only be able to run at a small percentage of their total capacity.Other countries around the world have cut their distances down to .m or even m.But British scientists say that m is the safest distance that two people who are not in the same household can be from one another - story: The Love Island host, , was tragically discovered dead at her North London earlier this year.An inquest will now be held in August with those involved including legal representatives to contribute remotely.The coroner is expected to be in the court itself as part of the proceedings.Caroline killed herself on February , a day after she had learned that the CPS was pursuing charges that she allegedly attacked her boyfriend Lewis Burton, , with a lamp.Caroline had pleaded not guilty to assault by beating, but killed herself at her East London home hours after learning prosecutors had decided to move forward with the case.The popular TV host had strongly denied the charge and her family and management slammed the CPS for pursuing the case branding it a show trial.Her mum Chris this week spoke out again over the tragedy - accusing the Crown Prosecution Service chief of repeating untruths about her daughter which she said left the ITV star feeling humiliated.It doesnt discriminate, touching the lives of people in every corner of society - from the homeless and unemployed to builders and doctors, reality stars and footballers.Its the biggest killer of people under the age of , more deadly than cancer and car crashes.And men are three times more likely to take their own le than women.Yet its rarely spoken of, a taboo that threatens to continue its deadly rampage unless we all stop and take notice, now.That is why The Sun launched the Youre Not Alone campaign.The aim is that by sharing practical advice, raising awareness and breaking down the barriers people face when talking about their mental health, we can all do our bit to help save lives.Lets all vow to ask for help when we need it, and listen out for others... story: NewsopinionDavid Lammy: Black Lives Matter protesters deserve to see action and lasting changeProtesters taking to Britains streets and toppling statues to highlight racism past and present are looking for answers not meaningless platitudes, Labour MP David Lammy writesShareCommentsByDavid Lammy MP:,  JUN NewsopinionLabour Shadow Secretary for Justice and MP for Tottenham David Lammy " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe Black Lives Matter movement demands action, not just rhetoric. Last weekend Matt Hancock, the Health Secretary, said of the Black Lives Matter protests: “Thankfully, this is all based in response to events in America rather than here.” This betrayed an attitude of arrogance, complacency and ignorance. Of course, the brutal murder of George Floyd triggered this moment of mass protest: first in the US and then across the world. But it has only gathered the momentum in this country, because prejudice, bias and, yes, racism, exists on this side of the Atlantic, too. Labour does not support how the protesters pulled down the statue of Edward Colston, but it should have been removed democratically a long time ago. story: NewsGovernments own coronavirus experts called for cash to help people in isolationEXCLUSIVE: Documents reveal SAGE wanted financial support for people who isolate for  days under the test and trace scheme - but an MP has accused ministers of ignoring itShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsSAGE suggested financial support for people who isolate for  days under the test and trace scheme" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailMinisters have been accused of “ignoring” a plea to hand extra cash to people who isolate under the new test and trace scheme. Documents show SAGE, the government’s scientic advisory group, suggested an “offer of financial support” to hard-up peoplethe NHS tells them to stay at home for  days. In a meeting on May , SAGE said the scheme needs a “high level of adherence” - and people might not comply “ they are impacted financially”. But no new pot of cash for self-isolating people, beyond what already exists, has been announced since that meeting. Statutory Sick Pay was extended near the start of the outbreak to those self-isolating due to Covid- - and is now paid from day one. But campaigners say the £.-a-week rate is not enough, and workers must earn at least £ a week to qualy. Lib Dem MP Layla Moran called for workers to get % of their usual salary up to £, a monththey self-isolate - as in the furlough scheme. The leadership hopeful said: “The Government must stop ignoring the science and ensure those required to self-isolate receive adequate financial support. “As SAGE has concluded, the test and trace system relies on high levels of compliance to succeed. “Yet ministers appear to have ignored this advice, forcing people into an impossible choice between financial hardship or breaking the rules by ing to work. “People must not be pushed into poverty for doing the right thing.”  Launched this month, the test and trace system tells anyone who’s had contact with a Covid- sufferer to isolate for two weeks. The SAGE comments came during a newly-published meeting to discuss the test and trace scheme. The scientists agreed: “A high level of adherence to requests to isolate is required for the system to be effective. “Risks include iniduals becoming less willing to comply…they are impacted financially from being asked to isolate. “An accessible offer of financial support to those in need could reduce the risk of non-adherence.”  But a DWP spokesman hit back: “Statutory Sick Pay was extended to employees who are required to self-isolate for this exact reason. “We’ve also made this more generous by making it payable from day one, as well as refunding employers with fewer than  employees the cost of up to two weeks’ sick pay. Employers can, and many do pay more than the statutory rate – something we encourage. “This government has provided an unprecedented package of support to help people through this pandemic including injecting £.bn into the welfare system, rolling out income protection schemes, mortgage holidays and additional support for renters.”The DWP said some of those ineligible for sick pay may be able to claim Universal Credit. In the same meeting, SAGE said the system should ask people to isolate even after contact with an unconfirmed case. Yet the government did not take up this advice. Instead, it is only asking people to isolatetheir contact had a positive Covid- test result. Some , contact tracers are already tracking down the movements of any new cases.

story: NewsMinisters should be worried about OAPs plan to disrupt TV licence fee systemEXCLUSIVE: The Silver Voices group is taking action in protest at moves to strip over-s of free TV licencesShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy Political Editor:,  JUN NewsMost over-s are due to lose free TV licences from August " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailMinisters should be “very worried” about a campaign by rebel pensioners to disrupt plans to strip them of free TV licences, their leader warned tonight. The Silver Voices group plans a “gum up the works” drive to hamper curbs which would see millions of over-s lose the leline. Director Dennis Reed wrote to the BBC outlining plans for the groupaposs members “to withdraw from direct debit arrangements with TV Licensing and to noty you that, in future, all payments and correspondence about the fee will be conducted by cheque and post”. Mr Reed told the Mirror last month the drive was aimed at making the cost of administering and enforcing the licence fee “much more expensive than keeping the free licence for a relatively small group”. In a reply to Mr Reed, seen by this paper, the BBCaposs controller for policy Paul Oldfield said: “Under the current schemes the vast majority of people pay for their licence by direct debit or other payment options that suit them so that they can pay in instalments for example.  “TVLoffers payment by cheque but has to collect the full licence cost without instalment options. “Under TVL’s current systems, we are trying to encourage customers not to post us information during this time.” Some . million OAPs are due to lose free licences, worth £. a year, from August .Curbs on entitlement were due to come into force on June  but were delayed by two months because of the coronavirus pandemic.The Mirror is campaigning to permanently save the benefit, with more than , readers backing the fight by completing coupons in the paper. The TV licensing system is run and enforced by outsourcing firm Capita. Silver Voices is urging its members to withdraw from direct debits and standing orders, only communicate with TV Licensing through post rather than email, pay by cheque or cash and use “creative but legal ways to complicate and delay payment” such as paying “slightly too much so that a credit note has to be organised”. Mr Reed dubbed it a “classic consumer-based campaign using reliance on labour-saving systems to force change”.  He told the Mirror: “The BBC is obviously very worried about the potential impact of our campaign and the Government should be too. “Our legal direct action against one of their favourite private contractors – Capita – who run TV Licensing should persuade the Government to work with the BBC to ensure that this essential benefit is retained.” The Conservatives pledged at the  election to protect over-sapos free licences for the rest of that Parliament, which was due to run until . But the BBC had already been handed responsibility for funding the leline from June , under a deal agreed in .

story: NewsBlack fast food worker told her natural afro was unprofessional and sent homeChristine Emelone claims the comment embarrassed her, left her feeling completely alone and says its proof that racism is still evident in BritainShareCommentsByChristine EmeloneKelly-Ann Mills:,  JUN NewsChristine Emelone was shocked at being told her hair was unprofessional " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters.
