about opening dates.ldquoI want to build upon the positive progress in managing the spread of the virus and begin to re-open our tourism industry in a safe and managed way, she said.The economy minister said progress on re-opening will depend on controlling the rate of transmission of the virus and confirmed that further work is under way to assess the potential to re-open pubs and restaurants and all other parts of the tourism sector.The Newry, Mourne and Down Council area relies heavily on tourism, attracting local, national and international visitors, but the numbers have crashed through the floor since the coronavirus lockdown measures were introduced in March.Last week, a number of country parks, harbours, tennis courts and beach car parks across the district were reopened by the local authority, with the National Trust and Department for Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairs reopening a number of its local attractions.They include car parks at Castlewellan and Tollymore forest parks, Saintfieldrsquos Rowallane Garden and Castle Ward on the shores of Strangford Lough.The reopening of hotels, guesthouses and caravan parks provides the glimmer of hope their owners have been hoping for, with the focus now in what measures they will be required to implement to ensure the safety of staff and guests.Mondayrsquos announcement by Mrs Dodds will help kick-start the local economy, with the reopening of the key tourist facilities welcomed by South Down MLA Emma Rogan and Downpatrick area councillor Dermot Curran.Ms Rogan has welcomed what she described as the ldquoroad map to support the tourism sector as part of the Covid- recovery plan.She said the tourism and hospitality sector was one of the worst hit by the global pandemic, with many in the sector seriously concerned about the future.ldquoThe move to allow hotels, hostels, caravan parks, guesthouses, bed and breakfast providers and others to open from July , subject to scientic and medical advice, will be warmly welcomed, said Ms Rogan.ldquoTourism is key to our economy right across the island, particularly South Down. The NI Executiversquos announcement will help those working in the industry to get back to work safely. Indeed, the safety of those working in the sector, as well as that of the wider public, will be paramount in all of this.Ms Rogan said that the reopening of tourist accommodation will depend on the rate of transmission, appealing to people to ensure this can go ahead as planned by continuing to follow social distancing guidelines.She added: ldquoIf we continue to work together, to follow the guidelines and stay safe and save lives then we can get our tourism economy open for business again.Cllr Curran said he was pleased that a major part of the tourism sector was scheduled to reopen and echoed calls for people to continue following public health advice, suggesting aldquochallenging world awaits all aspects of business in the months and years ahead.ldquoTourism is the districtrsquos number one product and, prior to the pandemic, generated hundreds of thousands of pounds for the local economy, helping sustain thousands of jobs, he continued.ldquoClearly, the safety of staff and the public is paramount moving forward and I have every confidence that those who run our hotels, guesthouses, caravan parks and other tourist accommodation will have this at the top of their agenda.Cllr Curran said he concurred with the economy ministerrsquos contention that enabling accommodation businesses to generate essential revenue will help to protect iniduals and livelihoods which support families and communities across Northern Ireland.He said hoteliers and tourist accommodation providers will be seeking clarity of exactly what services they will be able to offer, so that they can plan for reopening with confidence.Cllr Curran recently called for the umbrella group that represents Northern Irelandrsquos  councils to have a role in helping the tourism industry recover from coronavirus and hopes that this will happen.He said the Northern Ireland Local Government Associationshould be involved in the work of the Tourism Recovery Working Group set up by Mrs Dodds, agreeing that the tourism and hospitality sectors have a vital role to play in the countryrsquos economic recovery post-coronavirus.Cllr Curran added: ldquoThere is widespread recognition that tourism will have changed signicantly when the crisis ends, but I believe there are opportunities to build for the future.ldquoSouth Down and the wider Lecale area relies heavily upon tourism and the sector must be given every opportunity to recover as a healthy tourism industry leads to a healthy economy.Financial experts have suggested that % of pubs and restaurants and % of hotels in Northern Ireland may not reopen, but Cllr Curran hopes the estimations are wrong and these key sectors can recover helping the recovery of the local and regional economies..prettyPhoto

title: Meeting for Irish Street redevelopment plans
story: PLANS for the redevelopment of a major town centre site in Downpatrick were discussed at a key meeting yesterday.A steering group overseeing the redevelopment of the former Irish Street police station, a number of adjacent empty buildings and a Newry, Mourne and Down Council-owned car park met to discuss a new brochure which has been designed for the near two acre site.While it was suggested that the coronavirus pandemic is likely to delay the redevelopment of the huge site, traders and politicians are keen to see work starting on the eagerly-awaited economic regeneration of this historic part of the town.The local council and the Department for Communities are spearheading an ambitious regeneration project with the new brochure mdash understood to be still in draft form ndash designed to provide potential developers and other interested parties with an overview of the sitersquospotential and secure expressions of interest.A number of Irish Street businesses have already invested in upgrading their respective shop fronts while the former police base was recently given a fresh coat of paint as part of a revitalisation scheme.The development site stretches as far back as St Patrickrsquos Avenue and is also adjacent to the Irish Street car park, with council officials looking to make the brochure available to the pubic virtually.Described as a strategic and prominent location in the heart of Downpatrick, senior council officials, politicians and members of the business community are excited at the Irish Street sitersquos development potential.While the imposing former police station enjoys protected status and cannot be razed to the ground, it is hoped that potential developers will be able to come with an imaginative plan for the building.It has been identied as a development opportunity site in the Down Area Plan, with the area to the front included in Downpatrickrsquos conservation area.While it has been suggested that housing could form part of any redevelopment proposal, the building has been touted as a potential base for offices.Newry, Mourne and Down Council and the Department for Communities are keen to revitalise Irish Street and hope its redevelopment will act as a catalyst for the wider economic and social regeneration of the town.They are keen to retain Irish Streetrsquos uniqueness where residents and traders live and work alongside each other and ensure that there is adequate parking. There have already been suggestions that an underground parking facility at the current Irish Street car park would allow retail units to be built on top.Work was recently completed on a protracted public realm scheme in Irish Street and it is hoped that the redevelopment of the former police base will complement this project, which resulted in the provision of new granite paving, street furniture and lighting.Downpatrick councillors are keen to see the redevelopment proposal increase the number of shoppers to the town to provide a boost for existing traders who have been at the heart of the townrsquos economy for many years.It is also hoped to regenerate the town centrersquos night time economy with politicians eager for the Irish Street scheme to create a number of much-needed new jobs.Earlier this year, a number of Downpatrick councillors were given the opportunity to view the inside of the former police base and the expansive grounds to the rear.Local council officials say they are committed to working with the Downpatrick business community, residents and other stakeholders on the redevelopment of the Irish Street site and had been planning to meet with them to discuss the way forward prior to the coronavirus pandemic.In addition, the local authority aims to work alongside local people on the redevelopment proposal.Leading High Street brands including Marks and Spencer and Home Bargains have previously expressed an interest in the Irish Street location which is the last large scale development site remaining in Downpatrick town centre. However, it remains to be seenthat interest remains given the current economic climate.Downpatrick councillors say that they recognise the Irish Street regeneration project provides an opportunity to regenerate the town centre and provide a boost for existing businesses and hope that the project can be progressed..prettyPhoto

title: Minister asked to give assurances on bypass
story: STORMONT roads minister Nichola Mallon has been asked to make it clear that delivering Ballynahinchrsquos multi-million pound bypass remains one of her key priorities.The appeal has been issued by South Down MP Chris Hazzard mdash a former minister at the Department of Infrastructure mdash who is keen to see work starting on the poundm project.When he was at the helm of the Stormont department, Mr Hazzard signed off the eagerly-awaited bypass in December .Since then, there has been major progress to deliver the near two-mile scheme to link the Newcastle and Saintfield roads, with work already completed on a major archaeological investigation along parts of the route.Work was due to complete on the schemersquos economic appraisal before the end of last year, with roads engineers confirming recently that in order to advance the bypass schemersquos state of readiness, preparatory work on contract documents was ongoing to ldquominimise the time required to initiate a procurement competition, should funding become available for construction.The bypass, which would be the single biggest road scheme ever constructed in the district, is expected to take in excess of  months to build, with major new roundabouts proposed at the Belfast Road junction with the Saintfield Road and at the Newcastle Road junction with the Downpatrick Road.Mr Hazzard said while the coronavirus pandemic has consumed much time for all government departments, he does want to diminish Ms Mallonrsquos role in working constructively with her executive colleagues in mitigating the worst effects of the global emergency.But he said since that taking over the reins at the roads department five months ago, the minister has issued statements on electric bikes and hydrogen buses and what he described as ldquoplenty of positive soundings on other capital projects, but there hasnrsquot been a single word on the long overdue Ballynahinch bypass.ldquoThis is a relatively low-cost, yet strategic infrastructure scheme that is shovel ready. Yet it hasnrsquot featured in any of the ministerrsquos public commentary on her departmentrsquos priorities for the time ahead since taking office in January, said Mr Hazzard.ldquoIt is unsurprising then that local businesses and commuters are beginning to question the infrastructure ministerrsquos commitment to deliver this scheme.The MP says he has once again asked Ms Mallon to definitively set out that the Ballynahinch bypass remains a priority for her department and set out a timeline for commencing construction.He added: ldquoIn light of the severe economic impact of Covid- and ongoing Brexit uncertainty, the successful delivery of this project will be a vital step in improving both our local economy and the wellbeing of our local community in these dficult times.In a letter to Ms Mallon, the South Down MP said the bypass scheme is at an advanced stage and is as close to ldquoshovel ready as any other project in the government departmentrsquorsquos capital programme.He has asked the ministerthe Ballynahinch scheme remains a ldquopriority capital project, what stage is it currently at and when will construction work be signed off Responding to Mr Hazzard, a spokesman for the roads minister said that while she is currently faced with ldquoserious and challenging budget constraints, she has already stated that she is committed to working to find solutions that deliver better for communities and improve lives across the North.ldquoShe very much recognises that many in the local community support the provision of a bypass in Ballynahinch, the spokesman continued.ldquoIn finalising budget decisions, the minister is focused on addressing the need to fund essential infrastructure work, promoting a green recovery and getting other strategic projects underway.The spokesman said that in particular, Ms Mallon is considering her long term priorities for strategic road improvement schemes and how they might facilitate complementary improvements to promote sustainable travel choices, connecting people and communities, creating thriving and liveable places that enhance opportunities and our economy.The spokesman added: ldquoThe minister understands the frustration among the people of South Down at the failure of previous administrations to deliver important projects.ldquoShe has already set out her ambition to address regional imbalance with the delivery of projects and hopes elected representatives from across all parties and across the Executive will support her in securing the money to deliver strategic projects which improve both our economy and the wellbeing of our local communities in South Down and across the North in these dficult times..prettyPhoto

title: National Trust sites reopen
story: A NUMBER of local National Trust properties reopen from today.The National Trust has confirmed that Saintfieldrsquos stunning Rowallane Garden and Castle Ward and Mount Stewart mdash both on the shores of Strangford Lough mdash will be welcoming visitors after being closed for a number of weeks as part of the coronavirus lockdown restrictions.In total,  properties are reopening across the province, with Trust officials confirming that advance bookings will be required in order to limit numbers and maintain public safety. They say the reopening process will be ldquophased and gradual.The reopening comes after it was announced that Castle Ward is among the  most popular National Trust properties in the UK.Last week, Newry, Mourne and Down Council reopened Delamont Country Park outside Killyleagh, while the Department of Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairs reopened car parks at Castlewellan and Tollymore forest parks.National Trust director general Hilary McGrady said the organisation wants to provide safe, local, welcoming spaces for people and, wherever possible, gardens and parks and coast and countryside car parks will reopen.ldquoThe fresh air, bird song, big skies and open spaces people have missed will be there, but things will be very dferent, particularly at first, she said.ldquoWe want to thank people for their patience and support while we gradually begin reopening and welcoming our visitors.The reopening of Rowallane Garden has been welcomed by local councillor Robert Burgess.ldquoI am delighted this tourism jewel is to fully reopen which is good news for people wanting to get out in the fresh air and enjoy the spectacular scenery that Rowallane Garden has to offer, he said.ldquoIt is popular with locals and visitors alike and people will be very much looking forward to ing to enjoy walks along the many trails.Cllr Burgess says he has no doubt that the National Trust will have a programme in place to protect visitors, highlighting the need for people to continue social distancing and practise good hand hygiene.He also welcomed the reopening of Delamont Country Park which is also popular with local people and visitors.ldquoDelamont is one of our hidden gems and a number of exciting proposals have been drawn up to help with the regeneration of the country park and make it even better, he said. ldquoWhile the coronavirus has inevitably halted progress on this, I hope work on this scheme can progress when it is safe to do do.ldquoThere are three separate development phases stretching over the next five years aimed at maximising Delamontrsquos location on the shores of an internationally acclaimed waterway.Initial work includes transforming the way in which information on the -acre park is interpreted for visitors highlighting its wildle, flora and fauna, park events and its links with Strangford Lough.This work also aims to better communicate the history and heritage of the country park and increasing accessibility around the picturesque trail network to improve access to key features and locations.Cllr Burgess added: ldquoThere are very exciting plans for the future and what is proposed is in keeping with the nature of the country park. Funding opportunities are being explored and while this work will also have been interrupted, I hope that it will resume in the near future.ldquoTourism is the districtrsquos number one offering and post-coronavirus we will be relying heavily upon it.Facilities like Delamont, Rowallane Garden and Castle Ward are magnets which help attract people and spending power to our area boosting the economy..prettyPhoto

title: Newcastle’s Luke Northern Ireland eSailing champ
story: A NEWCASTLE sailor has become a Northern Ireland champion mdash without taking to the water.Luke McIlwaine was crowned Northern Ireland eSailing champion recently after beating the provincersquos best in a virtual regatta.The RYA launched its eSailing Spring Club Championship at the start of April.Around  sailors competed in their own club championships and eight club champions then competed in the NI final.Nineteen year-old Luke showed his skill by three races and was crowned NI eSailing champion.Luke went to compete in the UK final at the weekend and finished a highly creditable fth out of the ten finalists.Luke said: ldquoThere is definitely no lack of virtual regatta races to take part in, particularly involvement in the regular races that can be played every day has been excellent.ldquoThese races have such a high skill level from all sailors and they are the perfect practice ground.Lisa McCaffrey, RYANI Active Clubs co-ordinator said: ldquoDuring lockdown eSailing was an opportunity for sailors and non-sailors to keep some sort of connection with their sport.ldquoIt has been very popular and I think having these championships is a great way to bring our clubs together and keep members involved with the sport..prettyPhoto

title: Pompey dream
story: BALLYNAHINCH teenage soccer player Eoin Teggart has been given a massive career boost.The hugely talented  year-old has been offered a third year scholarship by Portsmouth.The Northern Ireland youth International joined the League One clubrsquos academy from Cltonville in September  and has blossomed ever since.He made his debut for the academyrsquos first team against Norwich City in the Leasing Trophy as helped set up two goals as Portsmouth reached the final against Salford City at Wembley Stadium.Academy manager Mark Kelly was full of praise for the youngster: ldquoEoin has got plenty of pace and crossing ability mdash now he just needs to hone in on a few things.He is one of three players to be offered third year scholarships by Portsmouth.Kelly added: ldquoThey all deserve this opportunity, but have to get their heads down and be ready to go again.The ultimate aim is to catch the attention of Portsmouth manager Kenny Jackett and secure a place in his first team squad.Before his move to Cltonville Teggart was part of a highly successful Ballynahinch United youth team that went unbeaten for two seasons in the South Belfast Youth League before spending some time at Ridgeway Rovers and Glentoran.He was also part of the County Down side that reached the SuperCupNI Premier final in .On the local soccer front meanwhile, Billy Heal has been appointed as the new first team manager at Dundrum United.Heal was unveiled at the weekend by club chairman Jim McIlwrath and Chris Hogg, vice-chairman and club captain.He takes over from Andy Smyth who will continue with the club as a player and committee member.For over  years Heal has been involved with football within South Down, starting off with the Valley Youth.For the last three seasons he was first team manager at Ballyvea, who led to a double in the Newcastle League.He then took Ballyvea into the Mid Ulster League where they gained promotion at the first time of asking, finishing runners-up to Annalong, and reached the final of the Foster Cup, which has still has to be played because of the coronavirus lockdown.A spokesman for Dundrum United said Healrsquos appointment had the committeersquos overwhelming support and that it was first time a person from outside the club had been appointed as manager.The spokesman said the the club was aiming for a top three finish in the league and winning at least one cup.ldquoBillyrsquos aspirations with Dundrum United are to install a winning mentality and a hard working ethos within the club with fitnesses his driving force..prettyPhoto

title: Schoolboy Fionn in charity walk for Action MS
story: A LOCAL schoolboy is going the extra mile to raise money for charity.Ten year-old Fionn McNulty will be walking from his home at Raholp to St Josephrsquos Primary School in Ballycruttle in order to raise much-needed funds for Action MS.Fionn, who is a P pupil at St Josephrsquos, will be accompanied by his grandfather, James Murphy, a former principal of the school.Fionn is no stranger to supporting the charity. He has been taking part in the Walk for MS since he was in P, following in the footsteps of his mum Joanne, who took part when she was at school.Despite the current lockdown situation Fionn is not going to be deterred in completing his own walk for MS.Fionn has been a top Action MS fundraising pupil for several years and last year he was presented with a special plaque at the annual Walk for MS Thank You Luncheon.The plaque was in recognition of him raising the fantastic amount of pound, which makes such a dference to those people with MS and their families in the local area.A spokesperson for Action MS said: ldquoAction MS recently celebrated  years of the walk for MS but unfortunately, like so many fundraising events, the walks which were due to take place in the spring and summer term have had to be postponed due to the current coronavirus pandemic.ldquoWe are therefore delighted that Fionn and James are taking Action and doing something so worthwhile, which will help Action MS to maintain vital support services to those who need it most.Adhering to the social distancing guidelines, Fionn and his grandfather will be walking from home to the school on Thursday, June .They will be leaving Raholp at am, crossing Loughmoney Road and Ballytrustan Road to Ballycruttle with Slieve Patrick and St Patrickrsquos monument as a perfect back.Their walk will be around five miles in total from one side of the parish of Saul and Ballee to the other. They hope to arrive at the school at pm where they will be met by teachers, pupils and representatives from Action MS.Fionn would like to thank all those who have supported him, friends and family and local businesses including Medicare Pharmacy, Downpatrick, and the Bank of Ireland.If you would like to follow in Fionnrsquos footsteps and organise a virtual event or challenge, walk, run, skipping, garden sports day, frisbee throwing, cycling, please get in touch with Action MS via Facebook or by email at info@actionms..prettyPhoto

title: Walking routes could bring tourism boost
story: DOWNPATRICK town centre could be formally linked to a number of surrounding historical and environmental attractions via a series of new walking routes to help provide a major tourism boost for the area.South Down MP Chris Hazzard has asked Newry, Mourne and Down Council to explore the possibility of developing so-called greenways and utilise old railway lines and riverside paths to help local people and visitors explore areas rich in ersity and history.He said the county town was fortunate to be surrounded by wonderful wildle and beautul nature spots which sit alongside its unique Patrician history which could all be linked to offer new opportunities for entrepreneurs, boosting the economy.Mr Hazzard argued that what the Downpatrick area has is the envy of most county towns throughout Ireland.But he pointed to a major problem mdash the lack of what he described as ldquocommunity infrastructure for attracting visitors that would ordinarily be interested in spending time exploring local attractions.Mr Hazzard said that within minutes of Downpatrick town centre are a host of key attractions of signicant historical interest, including the graves of St Patrick and Viking king Magnus Barelegs.ldquoThere is also the impressive Downpatrick and County Down Railway Museum and the only working heritage railway in the North, stretching out to Inch Abbey and the townrsquos racecourse, continued the MP.ldquoUnder the shadow of Down Cathedral we have the only visitor centre in the world dedicated to St Patrick, with the nearby Down County Museum located in the historic buildings of the th century gaol where United Irish leader, Thomas Russell, was executed in .The MP also pointed to the Mound of Down, Finnebrogue Wood, Quoile Nature Reserve and Delamont Country Park just a short journey away on the shores of Strangford Lough.ldquoTo the east of Downpatrick lies the historic Struell Wells and St Patrickrsquos first church at Saul, a unique site known widely as the Cradle of Christianity in Ireland. But, despite, a large amount of public land and pathways available to link these community assets, these attractions are poorly connected.Mr Hazzard said he has asked the local authority to ldquourgently look at rediscovering the public value of disused railway lines, abandoned riverside paths and overgrown public spaces in developing a Downpatrick greenway project that would help breath new le into redundant community infrastructure.ldquoLinking these wonderful local attractions would also help create exciting new public spaces where people can relax, enjoy nature or exercise, he continued.ldquoDelivering a greenway initiative would not only represent an exciting investment in our local tourism offering, but help create multiple, long-term employment and entrepreneurship opportunities, providing a strong  to build a much-needed, vibrant weekend and evening economy in the town centre.Mr Hazzard believes that developing greenways has the potential to make a huge dference to the lives of local people by providing the opportunity to enjoy traffic free access to fresh air and exercise.He is also confident that the initiative would encourage more workers and children to commute to work and school on foot or by bicycle and help provide a vital leisure resource for local people and visitors alike for generations to come. ldquoThe Covid- pandemic and subsequent lockdown restrictions has exposed the importance of community trails and public spaces to our collective well-being as a society, Mr Hazzard continued.ldquoOver recent weeks, our country roads and parks have been full of people seeking respite from isolation in the green, community infrastructure that ordinarily binds our communities together.However, it is clear that this infrastructure lags well behind many comparative regional, national and international locations.ldquoThankfully, however, unlike most major infrastructure projects which can be quite expensive and take the best part of a decade to complete, community green infrastructure can be delivered much quicker and at much less of a cost to the public purse.Mr Hazzard says he is confident that a new greenway project in Downpatrick represents an ldquoexciting opportunity on so many levels and deserves serious consideration.He added: ldquoI look forward to discussing this proposal with senior council management in the weeks ahead..prettyPhoto

title: line up of calves win over judges at calf fair
story: Breed judges from throughout the UK and Ireland were unanimous in their praise for the Pedigree Calf Fair and Beef NI Expo, held at the Balmoral Showgrounds in Belfast on SaturdaySpeaking after the one-day show, which featured three show rings and  native and continental beef breeds, event organiser and Chairman, David Connolly said: ldquoItrsquos been another fantastic event, and we certainly exceeded our strap-line lsquoBigger and Betterrsquo.ldquoThe  show has surpassed last yearrsquos inaugural event, attracting hundreds of spectators and more than  trade exhibits. Cattle entries were on a par with last year, and the judges were all impressed with the quality of the calves and the high level of stockmanship.ldquoOur judges have been busy throughout the day, and all were in agreement that the show provides a  for the provincersquos pedigree beef champions of tomorrow. Many of last yearrsquos winners went on to achieve top accolades and command high prices at local and national shows and sales. I have no doubt that many of this yearrsquos prize winners will follow in their footsteps.David Connolly continued: ldquoOne of the highlights of the day was seeing  of the countryrsquos best calves enter the show ring for the grand parade. This was a spectacular sight to round-off another successful show. Shows are a shop window for our pedigree livestock.Full results and photos of the Calf Fair in next weekrsquos Impartial Reporter.and the success of the event confirms that there is a need for a multi-breed beef show at this time of year. ldquoFrench judge Laurent Antignac was impressed with the professionalism of the young showmanship competitors. ldquoThey are a credit to Northern Ireland, he commented.While many eyes were firmly fixed on the ious breed classes, the overarching theme for the event was Beef Strategy . Several keynote speakers took to the stage to deliver short presentations aimed at helping farmers to encompass the breeding, nutrition and health needs of the industry.The seminar sessions included short presentations by Dr Francis Lively, AFBI William Minchin, MSD Animal Health and Paul Elwood, HVS Animal Health. title: pre christmas dairy farming event at eikon centre
story: The Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. The cows visit the robots on average . times per day averaging  litres per day with some exceeding litres. title: psni should explain how bid downplay northern ireland part its title got far
story: Jamie Bryson fails to overturn flag protest convictionMan dies on NI farmNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensCoronavirusFarmingNewsOpinionThe PSNI should explain how the bid to downplay the ‘Northern Ireland’ part of its title got this farThe term PSNI has been well established since shortly after it came into use in , and few people need to be told that it is an acronym for Police Service of Northern Ireland.By EditorialTuesday, th June , : amUpdated Tuesday, th June , : am""News Letter editorialThe previous well known name of the police, the RUC, was a similarly well known acronym, for Royal Ulster Constabulary. That name, of a fine police force that was respected in policing circles internationally by the time it was disbanded, had to be ditched, to placate nationalists. Then the injustice of - recruitment was introduced, in which less qualied and less suited candidates from Catholic backgrounds for officer positions in the force were preferred for admission over better candidates from Protestant and other backgrounds . This persisted until Catholic levels of recruitment reached a certain level. Yet this is not now enough for nationalism. As the Catholic percentage of recruits slides, there is a fresh clamour to introduce positive discrimination, aslower Catholic levels are always the fault of everyone . " fill"#ea" to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...But not only that, now there is push to re-brand the PSNI to downplay the Northern Ireland element. Remember that this comes at a time in which republicans have been getting civil servants to use the phrase north of Ireland in documents.Such terminology de-legitimises the fact of Northern Ireland, which exists under the principle of consent in the  Belfast Agreement — yet those who roll their eyes and insist that terminology does not matter typically depict themselves as defenders of that deal.The PSNI insist that they are not trying sideline the Northern Ireland part of their name. So why are they doing it The chief constable Simon Byrne’s answer is not impressive. He says that the new logo, which bafflingly makes the Cross of St Patrick colourless and thus immediately un-recognisable, and which gets rid of the word Northern Ireland on the lower part of the crest, will “better reflect the breadth and depth of what we do and to improve our connection to our communities”.There is no need for this change. In fact we need a better explanation from the PSNI how such a plan has got far.—— ——A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: victoria lagan dancers step out lockdown
story: Shock as ‘huge crater’ opens in road near PortaferryNurse ‘kicked in face’ and ‘two paramedics threatened’ by man receiving treatment in NI hospitalNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensCoronavirusFarmingNewsPeopleVictoria Lagan dancers step out of lockdownAn award-winning Coleraine dance school will step boldly out of lockdown this Friday.By David RankinMonday, th June , : pm""Victoria LaganYoung dancers from Victoria Lagan Dance and Drama are set to compete in the annual Ulster Dance Championships - via Zoom.They will perform their choreographed routines for the online competition - under aseries of strict Covid- precautions - in the grounds of the Riverside Theatre.For Victoria and her girls it’s a first but big step back to normality and follows weeks of rehearsals and meticulous planning.Victoria Lagan dancers have been rehearsing for weeks " fill"#ea" to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...Victoria explained: “We had been set to compete at the Ulster Dance Championships in April at Queen’s University but obviously the event was cancelled. They decided they would do a Zoom competition instead and we thought it would be great to enter some of our teams in a way to keep spirits high, keep training, keep motivated and most importantly - have some fun.“We have been doing weekly Zoom rehearsals every Tuesday with the mini, junior and intermediate competition teams, which has been amazing. I have been brought to tears on many occasions by seeing their beautul, smiling faces that I miss so much.“As the restrictions started to relax - where you could meet six people outdoors - some of the dancers have started to meet up outside for their Tuesday Zoom classes, which has been really special for them. I still haven’t seen any of them in person yet but am very excited to.”Victoria revealed that a productive collaboration with Causeway Coast and Glens Borough Council and the Riverside Theatre was key to making the event happen.The Ulster Dance Championships Zoom competition will feature Victoria Lagan dancers on Friday“I spoke to a member of the Council during a weekly FaceTime meeting I have with them regarding re-opening the studio and discussed the idea of us being able to do our Zoom competition together outdoors and they went through some of the legalities around it,” she said.“Once I realised this could be an option I contacted Roseanne Sturgeon, Manager of the Riverside Theatre, who was over the moon with the idea. She then had Megan Sheeran, who is the Technical Coordinator at the Riverside, to contact me to go through possibilities.“Megan has been such a huge help with this and has really gone above and beyond the call of duty in helping me do all the risk assessments so we could put it forward to be approved by Ulster University, Coleraine.“Thank goodness the Uni said yes! So we will be meeting on Friday outside at the back of Riverside - weather permitting - to compete in the Ulster Dance Championships via Zoom.”Victoria Lagan dancers will perform live on Zoom on FridayDancers and parents will have to adhere to a number of strict regulations to make sure the event passes off safely.Each dancer must use personal hand santisers, bring their own labelled water bottle, practice social distancing and have no physical contact at any time with other competitors or equipment.There will be security on site to check names of the children participating and only one parent per child will be allowed to spectate.First aid and fire marsahals will also be present and there will also be a special isolation room in the theatre should anyone develop symptoms.Markings on the grass outside the theatre will assist social distancing and no toilets will be in operation.Victoria added that anyone ignoring the safety measures will be asked to leave the site immediately.“It’s a lot of rules and regulations but we are eager to follow them and make this work so that we can give these kids a great day,” she added.“Our dancers are known for being well disciplined and I have the utmost faith that they will follow all regulations. Dancing means the world to these girls and I know how grateful they are to everyone at Riverside for allowing them to perform.“It’s going to be an amazing day! I know I will be bawling my eyes out start to finish watching them dance.“I am so proud of each and every one of them for putting % effort into their craft especially during these dficult times.”Thank you for reading this story on our website. s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentTHE Vale of Glamorgan Councilrsquos household waste and recycling centreswill reopen from Tuesday, May , but by appointment only.The booking system is to help comply with social distancing regulations, protecting residents and staff.Residents will be able to book an appointment from am on Thursday, May  via the Vale councilrsquos website.There will be  slots released for the next fortnight of bookings, beginning May  -  slots at Atlantic Trading Estate and  for Llandow.Any resident undertaking a journey to a HWRC within the Vale must comply with the current Government guidance and adhere to the social distancing measures that are in place to ensure safe operation and use of the centres.To begin with, only cars will be permitted access to the HWRC on Atlantic Trading Estate, Barry, and at Llandow.It will not be possible to provide access or appointment for trailers or vans at this time.Due to current demand, initially the council will be only be issuing one appointment slot per household, per month until further notice.Residents are asked to only make a bookingit is absolutely necessary, due to the sitesrsquo reduced capacity, and to arrive no earlier than five minutes before their allocated time to avoid any unnecessary queuing.The guidelines state that before visiting, residents must sort their waste or recycling appropriately to minimise the time at the site and residents must provide proof of residency eg driving licence or utility bill and display this in their windscreen while waiting to enter the site.Residents must follow on-site safety signs and guidance and residents should only exit their car when advised to do so by a member of site staff.Staff will be unable to provide assistance with lting or sorting so it is important to ensure all waste and recycling is manageable.Residents are also reminded thatthey do not respect social distancing or are abusive to staff they will be asked to leave site.It is important to remember that fly-tipping is a crime and leaving items outside the gates of a HWRC, on the street or in parks, woodlands and fields may result in a fixed penalty notice of up to pound being issued or even prosecution.Vale council cabinet member for neighbourhood services and transport, Cllr Peter King said: ldquoIrsquod like to thank residents for the assistance they have provided by storing items they wish to dispose of until now.ldquoUnfortunately, the period during which our household waste recycling centres were closed means there is now a backlog to clear, which is why we need a strict booking system until demand s to normal.ldquoWe appreciate this may cause some inconvenience but would ask residents for their patience at this time. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey title: welsh government resilience plan supports education over s
story: The plan helps ensure that learners are supported throughout the coronavirus pandemic.It is aimed at education for learners aged  and over, including further and higher education, apprenticeships, employability and adult learning.The plan identies the priority groups most in need of support and sets out the expectations of how education providers and the Welsh Government will work together in response to covid- and how key decisions will be communicated.Since education providers in Wales closed for face-to-face learning on March , colleges and universities have moved to remote learning, delivering online lectures, tutorials and reviews, as well as ensuring support for more vulnerable learners continues.The plan is ided into three phases ndash the current lsquorescuersquo phase is focused on ensuring education providers have immediate security of funding and arrangements for learning in place this academic year the lsquoreviewrsquo phase plans for potential changes this autumn and the lsquorenewrsquo phase will put arrangements in place for the remainder of the academic year -.The plan identies learners for whom the coronavirus is likely to cause the most disruption, including Year  and , and vocational learners who need to access colleges or workplaces to complete their courses.The Welsh Government has increased online resources for post- through its Hwb , with distance learning resources available for both learners and providers.The Resilience Plan follows the publication of the continuity of learning plan for schools, lsquoStay Safe. Stay Learningrsquo, published last month.Education minister Kirsty Williams has also announced that pound.m of capital funding, part of the Secircr Cymru programme, will be used to invite applications from Welsh universities to submit novel research proposals that could contribute to or boost the advancement of research that impacts covid-.Ms Williams said: ldquoThe coronavirus has presented huge challenges for both students and education providers, in both the immediate and the longer term.ldquoThis Resilience Plan will provide a clear focus so we can work together with our education partners to overcome these challengesldquoThis plan will complement our continuity of learning plan for schools, lsquoStay Safe. Stay Learningrsquo, but recognises the greater levels of autonomy and ersity of education and training provided by the post- sector.ldquoOur colleges, universities and training providers are critical to the national response to the coronavirus and the rebuilding of the economy. We are committed to doing all we can to support them.Minister for economy, transport and North Wales, Ken Skates said: ldquoWe do not only want to bounce back from this pandemic, but to build back better by creating a national economy which sees employment, wealth and prosperity sp equally across Wales.ldquoThe post- education sector will be crucial to this.ldquoAs we shape our recovery from the impacts of coronavirus, we are committed to doing all we can to provide a strong foundation for those looking for employment, learners, trainees and apprentices to flourish in the future.ldquoThis incredibly challenging period has already highlighted the talent, commitment and incredible resilience of training and learning providers in supporting iniduals here in Wales.ldquoItrsquos efforts like these that will help ensure we emerge from this crisis stronger than ever. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: new app provide specialist advice gps seconds
story: The Consultant Connect app has been fast-tracked for use in NHS Wales to help deal with the covid- outbreak and support primary care in the long term to offer better advice and guidance to patients.By accessing speedy advice the new app will help prevent unnecessary hospital admissions and referrals and ensure that those needing hospital treatment are managed accordingly.The core service, being rolled out across Wales, gives clinicians access to specialists in respiratory medicine, cardiology, diabetes, palliative care and acute medicine for covid.Health Boards can also add access to a range of local advice that is appropriate to their patientsrsquo needs.A GP or other clinician accesses the service either by dialling a phone number or using the Consultant Connect app.After choosing a speciality from a menu they are connected with a specialist in an average of  seconds.Mr Gething said: ldquoI am very pleased we are able to start rolling out the Consultant Connect in NHS Wales."This will help to support primary care to determine the right treatment for their patients.ldquoRight now it will save crucial time for health care professionals and reduce the story: BA said  job cuts were being considered in South Wales.The airline said it would act to try and protect as many jobs as possible.BAs parent company IAG has previously announced it was to cut , jobs from its , workforce.More storiesBritish Airways could cut  jobs at its Vale of Glamorgan maintenance baseThe proposals involve the Cardf Airport, Pontyclun and Blackwood site which employ maintenance and engineering staff. .Vale MS Jane Hutt said: "This is devastating news from BA which will affect highly skilled BAMC workforce and their families.ldquoThese workers are vital to the Conservative AM, Andrew RT Davies said: "This is devastating news for the workers at the three British Airways sites in South Wales."I remember when the site was first developed in Rhoose and this BA maintenance facility now employees over  workers and is the key to production at other sites in Pontyclun and Blackwood."The aviation industry has taken a hammer blow due to coronavirus and one of his articles that such a progressive town as Penarth was without an operatic and dramatic society, writes Penarth Operatic  Dramatic Societypresident, Mary Gardner.The response to his outcry was quickly taken up and within three weeks the Penarth Operatic Society was formed.The Societyrsquos first production was Gilbert  Sullivanrsquos Iolanthe, played at The Hippodrome which later burnt down, and what a glittering opening evening it must have been as the audience wore evening dress.The review featured next day read, ldquoBrilliant Initial Performance.More newsVale council issues warning over the use of parksFines increased for coronavirus lockdown breachesMarie Curie Great Blooming Tea Party goes virtualA few years later in , the drama section came into being and with it a new title of the Penarth Operatic  Dramatic Society, known affectionately as PODS.Since then PODS has progressed down through the decades with many highlights along the way.One being in  when PODS presented that great musical, The King And I, which won the premier prize at the Waterford International Festival, for which the company received a beautul Waterford crystal vase.The Town Council held a reception to honour the Society at the Paget Rooms, and James Callaghan, the local MP, paid his tribute to PODS saying it ldquoadded lustre and brought culture to Penarth.Another landmark was the play, Dear Octopus, by Dodie Smith produced for PODS th anniversary celebrations.One of our most challenging and exciting shows was Cabaret in , which won the National Operatic  Dramatic Associationrsquos award for Best Production and Best Stage Management and Technical presentation.More recently in , to honour and pay tribute to the many men who gave their lives in World War One, PODS presented the very special play, Last Man Standing, which also won a NODA award for Best Drama.In , PODS decided to do pantomime, and this has been a greatly gratying and popular addition to the companyrsquos output.Itrsquos wonderful to see children in the cast having on-stage experience, and then those children in the audience, perhaps for the first time, enjoying and loving live theatre.PODS is a very busy Society putting on four shows a year, a musical, two plays and a pantomime.Mrs Gardner said: ldquoThis year, sadly and very upsettingly after much hard work by all involved, the covid- virus struck as PODS had just set-up at the Paget Rooms ready for its run of Goodnight Mister Tom, only to be told the venue would be shut down next day.ldquoSince January, the Society had also been rehearsing for its May musical, The Full Monty, and that too has had to be cancelled.       ,params: .pushldquoNevertheless, when this terrible emergency is over the company will put on these two productions sometime in the future. ldquoPODS is proud of its achievement in giving much pleasure and entertainment to the local community with its first-class shows over the last  years, and its goal is to make its centenary in  with the help of its faithful audiences, friends and patrons.PODS is always ready to welcome new members, but at the moment it cannot meet or rehearse due to the covid- restrictions.It might be some time before restrictions are lted on groups being able to rehearse together, or audiences allowed back in theatres, meanwhile PODS members keep in touch on social media.There is a lsquoPODS public grouprsquo on Facebook, PODS quiz nights are being held on Zoom, and there is a website to keep track at podspenarth.org article_url   content_id   site_id s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentTHE RNLI in Wales has reacted to the Welsh Governmentrsquos plans for easing lockdown with an important safety warning.The Governmentrsquos changes, from Monday, June , will limit people to staying local and not generally travel more than five miles to reduce the risk of the coronavirus spreading.People from two dferent households in the same local area will be permitted to meet up as long as they are outdoors, and they maintain strict social distancing.The lesaving charity has called for the public to stay safe.RNLI lesaving manager, Matt Crofts said: ldquoAfter a warm spring coupled with the easing of a lockdown which has seen many of us unable to visit our local beaches, we expect many people to be eager to hit the coast.ldquoThe changes to Government guidance does not mean our coasts are safe.ldquoThe dangers that have always been there remain.ldquoWe ask those who are local to beaches to continue to be aware of the inherent dangers.ldquoOur strong advice to the Welsh public, who are not local to a beach, is to follow the Welsh Government guidance to meet outdoors and exercise locally and not to travel to the coast.ldquoAir temperatures may be warming up but the sea temperature remains consistently chilly all year, jumping or falling into cold water or spending longer periods than normal submerged in the water can lead to, potentially fatal, cold water shock.Water safety lead for the RNLI in Wales, Chris Cousens urged people to remember the safety advice.He said: ldquoStay in familiar surroundings and follow the Welsh Government advice.ldquoDo not put yourself, your family and emergency services at risk by taking risks or assuming it lsquowonrsquot happen to yoursquo.ldquoIf you do see someone at risk call  and ask for the coastguard.A high proportion of calls for the RNLI in Wales are to those who have been to people cut off by the tide, including during the lockdown period.Some parts of Wales have among the highest tidal range in Europe.A beach that was clear yesterday at pm might be completely covered in sea at the same time today.Mr Cousens said: ldquoIf you are heading out for a coastal walk, make sure it is safe before you go.ldquoAlways check the tide times and conditions before you set off and while out, be aware of your surroundings and keep an eye on the tide direction.ldquoAsk for local advice and look out for safety signs.ldquoAlways carry a means of calling for help and know to call  and ask for the coastguardyou or someone  is at risk.The RNLI is working to start a leguard service on several beaches in Wales and is in discussion with the Welsh Government, local authorities, landowners, and other partners.At present there are no RNLI leguards on beaches in Wales. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey but hopefully not for much longer.ldquoWhen the government announced all businesses were to close to protect society due to the covid- pandemic, it raised a lot of distress and uncertainty for many businesses, Beauty Within of Penarth included.But during the lockdown period, the pair have been - in line with ongoing government advice - been things in place to ensure they are ready towhen the go-ahead is given for the business to re-open.All existing and new clients will be assured of the usual warm welcome to the salon that previously existed.Both therapists have completed the Barbicide Certication for Beauty Industry Professionals, which endorses customer health and safety as priority.They have also introduced a few measures in support of government guidance which include adding perspex screens in treatment rooms for those clients who attend regularly for nail appointments.Masks will be worn at all times and clients will be offered a cleaning station for handwashing, which has been set up in both treatment rooms.They will continue to offer a personal experience to all their clients with appointments limited to two per the salon at any one time, which will support the social distancing measures which may be introduced.Clients will also be offered greater flexibility with booking appointments with opening hours being extended and available into the evening along with loyalty cards being introduced.ldquoAbove all  you can be sure to receive a warm welcome and can expect to leave feeling invigorated, Miss Laity added. ldquoWe have been overwhelmed and cannot wait to welcome you back with open arms very soon.The pair thank all their loyal customers for the kindness and support they have shown during this period of uncertainty.To book an appointment, call title: charity joins forces radio station tackle loneliness
story: The radio station has launched the ldquoWersquoll Meet Again campaign for listeners to get in touch and share a message for an older person in their lives that they are currently unable to be with due to the virus restrictions.These touching messages will be played out by the station for the recipients to hear. However, the charity is also keen to stress that not all older people are fortunate enough to have family and friends and thatrsquos why the work of Age Connects is so vital, even more so now.Nona Hexter, who runs the charityrsquos Senior Health Shop on Holton Road in Barry said: ldquoFor so many years we have been here for older people to pop in for information, advice and have a cuppa and chat with their friends and us too."It is tough not being able to be there in person for all of the vulnerable older people that we know but staff and volunteers are ensuring we are still here at the end of the phone, helping with shopping and in any way we can within safety guidelines.Karen Steele from Age Connects said: ldquoIn the first seven weeks of lockdown, we received , incoming calls for information, advice and support and in almost all cases we have managed to provide support or signpost people onwards."The charity is urging the general public and local businesses to ldquohelp us help to keep older people safe, well and reassured at this dficult time by making a donation to support its work at grass roots level where it is making a vital dference.A donation of just pound will help the charity make reassuring telephone calls. pound will help support staff and volunteers get shopping for vulnerable older people.If you are an older person needing support at this time, or know story: Chief Medical Officer for Wales Dr Frank Atherton." Shielding people can meet others and exerciseChief Medical Officer for Wales Dr Frank Atherton." s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentCHANGES to advice for people shielding from coronavirus are being introduced from Monday, June .People who have been shielding can now take exercise outdoors and meet people from another household, as long as it takes place outdoors.There are two changes to the advice for this group.Outdoor exercise is unlimited, as long as iniduals strictly follow social distancing rules and hygiene practices.Those who are shielding can meet outside with people from another household ndash but should not go into another personrsquos house or share food with them.Welsh Government minister for health and social services, Vaughan Gething announced the changes on Sunday, May .There are no other changes being made to the advice for those who are shielding at this stage.People who are shielding should continue to follow all the other advice previously given.They should not go shopping or attend work outside of home.They should continue to have food and medicine delivered to them.This advice comes from chief medical officer for Wales, Dr Frank Atherton.He said: ldquoRisk can never be completely eliminated but we advise those shielding to exercise at times that are less busy, so the risk of contact with others is reduced.ldquoWe have advised everyone in Wales to maintain social distance of two metres and keep good hygiene when meeting outdoors."For those who are shielding, strictly following these rules is vital.Mr Gething said: ldquoI am pleased that so many have been shielding so diligently ndash not only protecting themselves but also helping to protect our NHS.ldquoWe recognise how challenging these last few months, with minimal face-to-face contact with others, has been.ldquoI am incredibly proud of all those who have and continue to provide the vital support to enable people to shield.ldquoOur local authority partners, pharmacies, volunteers, and major food retailers have all pulled together to make shielding possible.The chief medical officer is continuing to develop his advice for shielding people after June .All who are shielding will receive a letter from Dr Atherton in the coming fortnight setting out the next steps. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey title: contact tracing system wales rolled out
story: From today, anyone who has a positive coronavirus test result will be contacted by a team of contact tracers and asked for details of everyone they have had close contact with while they have had symptoms.Close contact means anyone who has been within m of and had a face-to-face-conversation, had skin-to-skin contact with or have coughed on, or been in other forms of contact with for a minute or longer.It also means they have been within m of for more than  minutes or they have travelled in a vehicle with or sat near on public transport.All these close contacts will be followed up and will be asked to self-isolate for  days as a precaution to prevent the virus spreading further.From Monday, June  contact tracing will be supported by a new online system, which will give people the option to provide details of their close contacts electronically.Mr Gething said: ldquoTodayrsquos roll-out of the contact tracing element of our Test, Trace, Protect strategy is a signicant step forward in the gradual move out of lockdown.ldquoOver the last few months, thanks to the help of the public and the way they have followed the stay-at-home rules, we have managed to slow the spread of the virus to the point where we can today ease the regulations to enable family and friends to meet again.ldquoContact tracing is a tried and tested method of bringing outbreaks of infectious diseases under control and we hope it will do the same with coronavirus ndash but for it to be successful, we need everyonersquos help and cooperation in sharing details about their movements and contacts."We also need people to self-isolatethey may be at risk.ldquoThe scientic advice is clear ndash we need a contact tracing system in place before we begin to lt restrictions further.Health boards and local authorities are working together to deliver contact tracing.The system has been trialled in four health board areas over the last two weeks and more than  contact tracers have so far been employed.This number is likely to rise as the system is rolled out.Testing capacity has been increased to support contact tracing and home tests and tests at the drive-through centres for both critical workers and the public can be booked online.Full details of the contact tracing system are available at gov.wales testing-coronavirus article_url   content_id   site_id title: meet environment author stephen moss penarth bookstore online event
story: Mr Moss will talk to bookshop owner Mel Grfin about his new book, The Accidental Countryside, before taking questions from the virtual audience.This online event will take place at pm on Wednesday, June  via Zoom conference call.More storiesPopular book club moves online to adapt to isolationGrfin Books nominated for Best Independent Bookshop AwardIndependent bookshop to host crime author Matt JohnsonWhat links Britainrsquos Iron Age hill forts and urban skyscrapers Churchyards and docklands Golf courses and gravel pits Together, they make up The Accidental Countryside.Wherever you go in Britain ndash in the city, town, or countryside ndash you come across hidden havens for wildle.They may be home to sand lizards and stoats, adders and orchids, water voles and peregrine falcons.In The Accidental Countryside, Mr Moss tells the fascinating and uplting story of how wildle has taken advantage of us ndash often when we least expected it.He also asks a crucial question: without these places, will Britainrsquos wildle be able to survive Mr Moss is a lelong naturalist, broadcaster and author.His books include The Twelve Birds of Christmas, Wild Kingdom: Bringing Back Britainrsquos Wildle and The Wren: A Biography. Stephen is Senior Lecturer in Nature and Travel Writing at Bath Spa University.At a time when we are all exploring our gardens and local areas like never before, this is the perfect event to help you discoverthe natural world around you.Tickets cost pound and include a discount on book purchases.For information and to book online, visit ticketsource grfinbooks article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: schools wales urged open august holidays
story: An announcement on the re-opening of schools is expected this week, having been closed to the vast majority of pupils since March , with local authorities being told that at least three weeks notice will be provided,But despite the scheduled summer holidays set to start in mid July, leaving only approximately three weeks of lessons at most,the National Education UnionCymru claims that plans for the six week break to be brought forward a month had been abandoned.More NewsDeaths in Vale of Glamorgan jump  per cent higher in AprilBarry Dock and Penarth leboats seventh launch to tide stranded people on Sully IslandMeet environment author Stephen Moss at Penarth bookstore online eventUnion secretaryDavid Evans, in a Facebook post, said that such a move would result in a -week term in the autumn with just a one-week break in the middle for the teachers, adding that thiswould mean breaking summer arrangements and resulting ldquocontractual issues, describing such plans as a ldquonon-starter.But Arfon MS Sian Gwenllian says thatbringing this yearrsquos summer holidays forward should continue to be ldquofully explored, suggesting a phased and gradual re-opening of schools in August rather than September, but onlyit was safe to do so.Plaid Cymrursquos education spokesperson claims there could beldquoeducational advantages in bringing forward the start of the autumn term.This, she added, could further pave the way for permanent changesand a re-configuring of the traditionalthree term year in a way that would be ldquoless disjointed andmore in tune with modern-day needs.ldquoThe educational advantages of bringing this yearrsquos summer holidays forward and beginning the autumn term in August should continue to be fully explored, she said.ldquoBefore the Coronavirus crisis there were on-going discussions about school term s and the need to change from three to four school terms and making the summer holidays shorter.ldquoWith need to re-visit those discussions in the wake of Coronavirus and now may be the time to consider changing school terms permanently and toreconfigurethe annual school pattern.She added that the current practice ofldquointense half terms followed by a short holiday has caused both teachers and pupils to become tired, claiming that many teacherssay that the summer term is ldquotoo long ndash especiallyfor children who are not supported with their learning at home.She concluded,ldquoAt the moment in Wales, terms are of dferent swith holidays coming irregularlyand yet research shows that continuity and progression are importantelements of learning.ldquoMany teacherssay that the summer term is too long, with the first few weeks of the autumn term being used for catch-up, especiallyfor children who are not supported with their learning at home.ldquoIn the meantime, we must crucially continue to refine remote learning. This should be central to the plans for the gradual re-opening of schools. It should also be integral to future planning too as we continue to strive to close the digital poverty ide and the attainment gap.ldquoThe focus of our education system must be on engaging with every pupil and ensuring no child is left behind.A Welsh Government spokesperson said: ldquoThe Welsh Government is working closely with unions, local authorities, scientists and education staff to decide on the next steps for education in Wales and the Minister intends to update further this week. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: check catch prepare summer september   wales schools enter next phase
story: Education minister Kirsty Williams MS says all schools will start the next phase on Monday, June , with the term extended by a week, therefore ending on Monday, July .In the next academic year, beginning in September, the intention is that the autumn half-term break will be expanded to two weeks.In each school there will be a phased approach.More storiesWelsh Government education minister Kirsty Williams sets out thinking on schools Welsh Government provides schools with new mental health supportSchools in Wales will remain closed on June , announces education minister Kirsty WilliamsYear groups will be split into cohorts with staggered starts, lessons, and breaks.This will mean, at most, a third of pupils present at any one time, though schools may need time to reach this level of operation.There will be much smaller classes, providing secure dedicated time with teachers and classmates.This time will include online and personalised classroom experience, getting children and teachers ready for a similar experience in September.Next week, the Welsh Government will publish guidance to support schools, as well as further and higher education institutions.This will include information on managing their facilities and logistical arrangements, including buildings, resources, cleaning and transport.The Government is also publishing a paper from its covid- Technical Advisory Group, representing the latest understanding of the virus with respect to children and education.Further Education colleges are ensuring that appropriate measures are being taken to re-open for face-to-face learning from Monday, June .They will prioritise those students requiring licence to practice assessments and vulnerable learners.This follows close working with government and the joint trade unions.Guidance for childcare providers will also be published in the next week, supporting them to increase the numbers of children in attendance alongside schools.Ms Williams said her announcement gave schools three and a half weeks to continue preparing for the next phase.She said: ldquoWe will use the last weeks of the summer term to make sure pupils, staff and parents are prepared ndash mentally, emotionally and practically ndash for the new normal in September.ldquo June means there will have been one full month of test, trace and protect, which will continue to expand.ldquoI can also announce that teachers will be a priority group in our new antibody-testing programme.ldquoAs we continue to keep Wales safe, this approach will be critical.ldquoThe evolving science suggests that warm weather and sunlight gives us the best opportunity to ensure more time in school.       ,params: .pushldquoWaiting until September would mean almost half a year without schooling.ldquoThat would be to the detriment to the wellbeing, learning progress and mental health of our young people.ldquoThis is and has been a worrying period for us all.ldquoI know that many will feel apprehensive.ldquoWe have not rushed this work and this decision.ldquoThe three-and-a-half-week period before the next phase also gives us time to keep watch on developments where and provides further check-points to review evidence and the roll-out of testing.ldquoThis is the best practical option that meets my five principles which underpin my decision making.ldquoI am also convinced that it is only by ing to their own school that we will see increased attendance from our more vulnerable and disadvantaged children.ldquoWorking together we will secure equity and excellence for pupils as they check in, catch up, and prepare for summer and September. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey the coronavirus pandemic in March this year.The drive thru in the Ty Verlon estate-based store is located near the roundabout which provides access to and from Wenvoe, Cardf, Dinas Powys, Sully, and Penarth.Other drive thrus to re-open include the Cardf stores at Culverhouse Cross, Excelsior Road, Cardf Bay, Longwood Drive, and Newport Road.Extensive queues formed when two drive thru reopened in Pencoed, Bridgend, on Tuesday, June .A McDonaldrsquos spokeswoman said: "This is only possible following the hard work of the teams in our  pilot restaurants."Our employees, franchisees and suppliers have worked tirelessly to implement new procedures to enable safe working so that we can now help all parts of the UK and Ireland to enjoy theof the Big Mac."With fewer employees working in our kitchens and service areas, our teams will still need your patience and support as they continue to adjust to the new ways of working."Face coverings, gloves, perspex screens and new safety and hygiene processes mean it will look dferent, it will take a little longer and as we have seen in the pilot restaurants, we expect demand will be high."Please bear with us, we will continue to put our people first ndash their safety is our priority."She added: "In the last week, on occasion, we have taken the decision to close drive thru lanes where demand has impacted local communities or the
